#1367SourcePosted onPatch 2.2.3
Edited onundefined		Mojofabulous
I just did a little paper math which is probably grossly inaccurate. Assuming a 30% armor mitigation and 25% crit rate and spamming evic every...I'll say 30 seconds which I think is generous for a 5point evic, it puts your average increase at 175 dmg. That is 5.83dps. Compare that to whatever increase the 2pc T4 gives and the increase/decrease in stats you get from switching from T4 to T5 and there's your answer.

EDIT: Did a quick look, adding 1ap to my spreadsheet gives about .34dps. If the 2pc T4 bonus is valued at 50 for you then that's ~17 dps for you. Interesting to note that set bonus is only worth 2.34ap for my current gear....
Last edited by Mojofabulous : 11/04/07 at 2:16 PM.
#1368SourcePosted onPatch 2.2.3◊ Kytrarewn
Originally Posted by Mojofabulous

EDIT: Did a quick look, adding 1ap to my spreadsheet gives about .34dps. If the 2pc T4 bonus is valued at 50 for you then that's ~17 dps for you. Interesting to note that set bonus is only worth 2.34ap for my current gear....

Doing some quick spreadsheet work with both the gear and DPS spreadsheets, the value of 1AP is about 0.2-0.25 DPS for me right now.

Considering the '3DPS' number that I came up with earlier, or one 5pt evisc every 90 seconds (including crit rate and 20% armor), that comes out to an average of 3DPS or 5AP on average.

As such, the set bonus seems to be ~ 12-15AP, or just BARELY enough that it's worthwhile to use the deathmantle/skulker's/engineering pieces over using the netherblade equivalents (since the deathmantle handguards, engineering hat, and bloodsea brigand's vest are definitive upgrades).

Skulkers => Netherblade is a loss of ~ 19 effective AP.
Deathmantle => Netherblade shoulders is a loss of about 27 effective AP.

Netherblade 2pc bonus is weighted at 56AP.

So, weighing in the 2pc T5 bonus at 10AP (3DPS x 3AP/DPS) we end up being able to justify wearing the T5 pieces over the netherblade equivalents.

Is it tighter than I'd like it to be? Yes, probably, but it also allows us to justify taking T5 pieces on the way to the very significant 4pc bonus.
#1369SourcePosted onPatch 2.2.3Koosai
Might have missed someone mentioning this in here, but this thread mentions that the backstab and sinister strike calculations are off in the sheet. Basic summary is that the talents like opportunity, supprise attacks and aggression are not (1+aggression)*(1+supprise attacks) but instead (1+aggression+supprise attacks).
#1370SourcePosted onPatch 2.2.3Macblade
I just wanted to double check, since I hadn't heard anything in a while, a new version with 2.3 items and talent changes has not been finalized quite yet, correct? Any updates on when that might be a possibility Ald?

Thanks
#1371SourcePosted onPatch 2.2.3Sarlunas
It appears that the 5s cycle in the sheet currently refreshes snd as soon as 5 cps are reached, in builds without relentless strikes it would be better to refresh it as seldom as possible to waste less energy (at the expense of wasted cps). I understand the sheet was designed around a narrow spectrum of builds and so it might not be easy/worthwhile to make it more general, but I thought I'd mention it. I'm just trying to get an idea of how much dps is lost by picking up Cheat Death, if it goes live in its current form it looks quite interesting and surprisingly the 5s cycle appears to be an option for this build.

#1373SourcePosted onPatch 2.2.3◊ Aldriana
Originally Posted by Koosai
Might have missed someone mentioning this in here, but this thread mentions that the backstab and sinister strike calculations are off in the sheet. Basic summary is that the talents like opportunity, supprise attacks and aggression are not (1+aggression)*(1+supprise attacks) but instead (1+aggression+supprise attacks).

Originally Posted by Sarlunas
It appears that the 5s cycle in the sheet currently refreshes snd as soon as 5 cps are reached, in builds without relentless strikes it would be better to refresh it as seldom as possible to waste less energy (at the expense of wasted cps). I understand the sheet was designed around a narrow spectrum of builds and so it might not be easy/worthwhile to make it more general, but I thought I'd mention it. I'm just trying to get an idea of how much dps is lost by picking up Cheat Death, if it goes live in its current form it looks quite interesting and surprisingly the 5s cycle appears to be an option for this build.
This is true. Unfortunately, there's not an easy way to fix it, and, frankly, I'm not much inclined to worry about it, either, since builds without Relentless Strikes are so few and far between (and, almost univerally, are terrible) that being slightly off in those cases does not strike me as a large concern.
#1374SourcePosted onPatch 2.2.3Sarlunas
While 0/28/33 is certainly inferior dps compared to 11/28/22 I'm not sure the difference is as big as one might think (unless murder applies). Anyway I was just hoping there would be an easy fix but if not then forget it.
#1375SourcePosted onPatch 2.2.3Mojofabulous
Originally Posted by Sarlunas
While 0/28/33 is certainly inferior dps compared to 11/28/22 I'm not sure the difference is as big as one might think (unless murder applies). Anyway I was just hoping there would be an easy fix but if not then forget it.
It's not a huge difference. On a blasted lands mob after 25mins of attacking with each build the difference was 35dps unbuffed without using cooldowns. Yes, attacking without ruthlessness or relentless strikes SUCKED, but the dps was still relatively close and you get cheat death, which just owns.
#1376SourcePosted onPatch 2.2.3jacklowry
Boundless Agony > Fang of Vashj?
Hi. First off, thanks for all the hard work put into this spreadsheet. It really is an invaluable resource and has upped my game considerably.

This may have already been answered, but I had a question about the respective worth of Boundless Agony vs. the Fang of Vashj. I'm combat daggers (15/41/5) despite the dps-gimp as compared to swords, mainly because I enjoy playing daggers and because there's a glut of sword rogues in my guild. At any rate, I noticed the Boundless Agony is listed as an upgrade to Fang of Vashj on the Roguecraft 101 Spreadsheet, ostensibly based on the info given here.

Now, with the Fang of Vashj in my MH (Searing Sunblade in OH), it has a value of 1197.06 and says the Boundless Agony is a 14.31 UG. However, putting the Boundless Agony in my MH has a value of 1146.30 (i.e., -50)

I realize the changes are somewhat dependent on everything else I'm wearing. Regardless, I guess my question is, would y'all consider the Boundless Agony a worthwhile UG to the Fang of Vashj to spend DKP on, or is it just a sidegrade? I presume some people will answer, "use the spreadsheet, yo", but the spreadsheet seems to tell me it's a downgrade, which is not how it's spelled out on the roguecraft thread.

Thanks in advance and, once again, great job.
#1377SourcePosted onPatch 2.2.3presagio
New Version ?
I have searched the thread for a version of the sheet with 2.3 patch gear but i could not find it, reading the posts it seem to exist.

#1378SourcePosted onPatch 2.2.3
Edited onundefined		Katherine
Comparing [Fang of Vashj] and [Boundless Agony] is quite a problem, they have the same base dps, min and max damage. It really boils down what works best with your equipment. If you already have some Armor Pen, Boundless Agony might get on top due to increased gain when stacking Armor Pen. Fang of Vashj looks more like a generally good Dagger, Weapon Expertise, AP, Stamina. And don't forget that you loose the expertise rating when switching the Fang for Boundless Agony, which is one of the top3 stats in 2.3 to have.

Generally i'd say its a sidegrade or even dare saying "pvp gimmick". On a more objective note, plug it in the spreadsheet, if its within 20 EAP of the old, watch the resulting dps closely, if its less than a double digit change, don't bother shelling out major DKP.


Originally Posted by presagio
I have searched the thread for a version of the sheet with 2.3 patch gear but i could not find it, reading the posts it seem to exist.

Can i have a link to test it ?
Free file hosting by Savefile.com
Don't ask questions, its no official version, not supported by Ald and not proof read on the changes, take with major grain of salt.
Last edited by Katherine : 11/08/07 at 5:18 AM.
#1379SourcePosted onPatch 2.2.3letha
if you already have 5 weapon skill (expertise come 2.3) from another source, boundless has a higher dps value, however if fang of vashj would be your only source for weapon skill it will have higher value since the first five points of weapon skill are the single highest dps boost a melee can itemize against a (73+) mob. have you considered trying mutilate with boundless agony and fang of vashj? i found my raid dps as 41/20/0 mutilate with ashtongue trinket to be noticeably higher than 15/41/5 and it's much more fun to play.
#1380SourcePosted onPatch 2.2.3Katherine
letha your point on weapon skill is correct so far pre-2.3, as the first 5 points of weapon skill average to about 3% hit against lvl73. Come 2.3 though, Expertise doesn't give a THAT big jump for the first 5 points as it scales linear with its 0.25% / skill.

Do you have plans to include resistance gear into the spreadsheet so that we may compare items and numbers for resist-based fights? This is perhaps a moot point as we only have one such fight currently, but it may be something useful to include in the future (Sunwell?, WotLK?).
#1390SourcePosted onPatch 2.2.3Katherine
Originally Posted by nelalas
I apologize if this question has already been addressed; I did not find anything during my thread search.

Do you have plans to include resistance gear into the spreadsheet so that we may compare items and numbers for resist-based fights? This is perhaps a moot point as we only have one such fight currently, but it may be something useful to include in the future (Sunwell?, WotLK?).
You can add gear easily yourself.
1. Unhide the armors sheet
2. Copy the whole row of one item by clicking in front of it (take items from the middle, dont take set-items, will give strange results due to copied set-boni )
3. right click in front of the copied row and insert cells here, you will have cloned that item now
4. rename it and adjust the stats accordingly
5. Profit

#1392SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0♦ Aldriana
Umm... my immediate question would be "to what extent does it not already do so"? Most of the relevant Sub talents are already in and fully supported; the only ones missing are Dirty Deeds and Shadowstep; if the question is "do I plan to add those", the answer is yes. If the question is "will Hemo be updated to reflect it's new damage", the answer is also yes. If the question is "will there be a Hemo debuff damage estimate", the answer is probably not. I can't think of anything else that would need to be changed; if there is something, let me know and I'll see what I can do.

#1394SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0♦ Aldriana
My sense is that it's usually going to recommend 5s4.7r, which you may recognize has the 5s5r5s5r5s4r cycle that sometimes got mentioned for Heme pre-expansion. Basically, run 5s5r, and every 3 or 4 cycles when you notice your SnD uptime is getting tight, drop in a 4 point rupture.
#1395SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0♦ Shaker
Well, that'll certainly be easier to manage than my current 4pc T4 "Dear lord my cycles are wack" state. I suppose a checkbox for "I'm a raid leader and I can't micromanage my cycles" isn't coming in .9.. :P
#1396SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0♦ Aldriana
Honestly, with any reasonable SS or Hemo build, you can't go too far wrong by doing 5s5r. If you look at the actual damage difference between that and Xs5r, the real damage difference tends to only be a percent or two, so as a "lazy cycle" it's pretty much universally a good choice. So even with 4/5 T4, you can always fall back on that if events are being too distracting. Most combat builds will run it with slack, as will combat hemo with 2/5 T4, and the rest of Hemo builds will just need to trim a rupture every minute or two.
#1397SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0♦ songster
Originally Posted by Aldriana
My sense is that it's usually going to recommend 5s4.7r, which you may recognize has the 5s5r5s5r5s4r cycle that sometimes got mentioned for Heme pre-expansion. Basically, run 5s5r, and every 3 or 4 cycles when you notice your SnD uptime is getting tight, drop in a 4 point rupture.
Just as an aside, on our VR gank last night (after our first Vashj kill, woo!) I found myself doing something similar to this with Eviscerates, what with VR being unrupturable. I'd get S'n'D up, then do 5e, then do the biggest S'n'D I could, then 5e again, etc. When my S'n'D got up to 5 points, that gave me enough slack to chain together two 5e in a row.

I guess you'd describe that as ns/5e , with added 5e whenever there was enough slack time. In practice the "cycle" ended up as something like 1s/5e/2s/5e/3s/5e/4s/5e/5s/5e/5e

Was this the optimal strategy, or should I have locked myself into something consistent (say 3s/5e)? It certainly felt like the variable size S'n'D gave me more scope to adjust for procs, and to slot in things like BF and AR as appropriate.
#1398SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0Carnivori
Now that 2.3 is live, our hit rating cap is 363 right? Just checking, so i don't change 8 gems for no reason :P

#1400SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0♦ Shaker
Yes, hit cap is now 363 - again, nothing particularly special or important about getting to the hit cap.

Is 1 point of agility better than 1 hit rating for you? (the easiest place to see this is the gem recommendations for yellow slots - are they hit rating gems, or hit/agi gems?). If agility is better, use Warp Burgers (20 agi), if not, use 20 hit food.

#1403SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0♦ Aldriana
Originally Posted by Shaker
Yes, hit cap is now 363 - again, nothing particularly special or important about getting to the hit cap.

Is 1 point of agility better than 1 hit rating for you? (the easiest place to see this is the gem recommendations for yellow slots - are they hit rating gems, or hit/agi gems?). If agility is better, use Warp Burgers (20 agi), if not, use 20 hit food.
One thing to keep in mind about this is that 363 is the hit cap against level 73s. The hit caps against levels 70, 71, and 72 are 300, 308, and 316. Hence, in terms of everyday gear - gear that you're going to be using against trash or against boss adds that may not be level 73 - I would argue that getting above 300 hit is not only nothing special but in a very real sense counterproductive. As usual, one wants to select the gear that is independently good rather than focusing on achieving any particular hit number, but personally if I found my gear starting to creep significantly above 300 hit I might regem for less hit.

In terms of hit food: I suspect most combat rogues will find it optimal, but, again, that's why we have spreadsheets. This is another reason to try to keep some separation from the hit cap; if you have 350 hit initially you can't make use of hit food even on boss fights.

Distilling this all down to it's key points: I personally am not planning on re-gemming *anything* based on the changed hit cap. The level at which hit starts to soft-cap (due to hit cap on level 70-72 opponents) has only changed by 15, and against level 73s where you might want a bit more hit than before there is hit food to help close the gap. Moreover, your *actual* chance of hitting mobs hasn't really changed that much, as Weapon Expertise means that even if your miss rate is a bit higher than before, your dodge rate is a bit lower, so in the net, not a whole lot has changed.

Originally Posted by Carnivori
Yeah, got my hit rating from 296 to 346 with reasonable gem changes. I plan on keeping the hit rating above 330 at all times myself, dunno if it's the best way or not tho... Hey Ald, coming up with new version of sheet soon? One that has the new hit cap n new items, atleast the nynjah's Btw they're the best boots in the game atm, right? Kinda even with shadowamaster's but because you need to stack hit more nynjah's win.
Which brings me to the topic of posts like this. I'm not trying to pick on anyone in particular; this just happens to be a post on the very topic under discussion on the same page, but this is certainly a philosophy that has appeared any number of times throughout the first 1400 posts in this thread. So to make the point perfectly clear:

THE CONCEPT OF "NEEDING TO STACK HIT" IS TOTAL BS.

There is no circumstance under which one "needs" to stack hit. As a general rule, items with hit on them are good, yes. But regardless of your current amount of hit, and regardless of the amount of hit on the items in question, if item A is better than item B, you should use it.

In this particular case: for most rogues for whom the comparison is relevant, Shadowmaster's are better than Nyn'jah Tabi. Hence, regardless of your current hit, if you have the choice between them, you should use Shadowmaster, because they're better. Yes, they have less hit, but THAT DOESN'T MATTER. There is nothing special about having your hit being more than any particular number. Using an item that causes you to do less total DPS because you want your hit to be 300 instead of 275 is, frankly, ludicrous.

Now, I'm not saying that Nyn'jah Tabi aren't good. They are. They're great boots, and many rogues are going to use them for a long time. But to say that they are better than Shadowmaster's purely because they have more hit is just plain wrong.

With regards to the question of when the next version will come along: I'm still aiming to make my previous estimate of around Thanksgiving.

I should note, however, that I've started to feel a bit burnt out on the whole "spreadsheet" thing - hence, while I do plan to keep it up-to-date with mechanics changes and whatnot, I'm currently thinking that I probably won't be making significant UI changes as I've talked about in the past. That is, I will keep the sheet more or less updated and correct, but, barring some significant change in my enthusiasm level for the project, there probably won't be a lot of new features from here on out.
#1404SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0Krennick
Kudos to Aldriana.

I have followed this thread to the benefit of my rogue alt, and posts by Aldriana before this thread existed and I am staggered by the amount of work you have put in - not just to make your spreadsheet the best it can be, but to babysit and handhold and explain when people come up and ask something they should be able to figure out themselves.

I understand the burnout, and my only advice here is: Tend to your burnout before it becomes permanent.

Burnout is fixable, but you need it to go to a slow burn level for probably at least 2-3 months before new ideas and motivation will surface. Don't let anyone guilt you into putting in more effort at a time when burnout is in play. Make sure you feel that you are taking a break from the work related to the spreadsheet in a meaningful way.

While I'm a big fan of the spreadsheet and would certainly love to see a version updated for 2.3, I think we all need to step back and take a deep breath and realize that Aldriana will release it when it's ready and the only thing that can be accomplished by pushing for it is adding to burnout and alienation - and wasting his(her?) time responding to posts. As far as I'm concerned if it comes out in a months time it'll be all the more eagerly anticipated for it.

In the interrim Vulajin's Roguecraft 101 thread is a wealth of information, and for gear selection he's even walking us through how to assess the damage potential of items. If it's really important to you to know which item of two is better - go do some calculations or make some updates to the spreadsheet of your choice. If it's not really important but it'd just be nice to know - wait for the spreadsheet to come out or go look at the dps spreadsheet.
#1405SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0royaljester
Originally Posted by Aldriana
Now, I'm not saying that Nyn'jah Tabi aren't good. They are. They're great boots, and many rogues are going to use them for a long time. But to say that they are better than Shadowmaster's purely because they have more hit is just plain wrong.
I think the big reason I personally felt they were better off the top was the insane amounts of hit you could get from one item. There are several items in BT/Hyjal that have 0 hit on them and yet are still amazing pieces. I personally will be picking them up for the interim of Sharhaz boots, because they are that good and almost a side-grade to the Shadowmaster's according to your spreadsheet. I agree, don't socket/stack hit like it's going out of style, but to the same degree, you can't go wrong putting hit in a lot of spots.



I should note, however, that I've started to feel a bit burnt out on the whole "spreadsheet" thing - hence, while I do plan to keep it up-to-date with mechanics changes and whatnot, I'm currently thinking that I probably won't be making significant UI changes as I've talked about in the past. That is, I will keep the sheet more or less updated and correct, but, barring some significant change in my enthusiasm level for the project, there probably won't be a lot of new features from here on out.
Def take care of yourself before us. I know that now that I'm in BT/Hyjal, I rarely check the spreadsheet anymore because so many of the items are jsut pure upgrades, no matter how you look at it, but again,

Thank you for all your work on this sheet and time you've spent. I hope it all works out for you but don't let this sheet burn you out in having fun.

If it's becoming too much, like Shaker said, we'll make do; just take care of your own things and take a break from it. But really, I tip my hat to you as your hours spent and hard-work has most definitely helped me out along the way. You don't hear this enough, in my opinion so: Thanks man.
#1408SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0royaljester
Also, something I know has probably been proposed before, but "What about letting some of us help with the mundane things, even more so than we do now". I know to keep a sheet like this alive, keeping the main architect going is the main focus, and if any of the posters who enjoy your work so much can help out with little things, or updating things, send to you and you can check it. I know sometimes that leads to more work and may be why you haven't already begun to delegate, but if you think it could help, let us know, I'm pretty sure the community has it in them to help out for something they care about.
#1409SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0♦ Aldriana
Originally Posted by royaljester
Also, something I know has probably been proposed before, but "What about letting some of us help with the mundane things, even more so than we do now". I know to keep a sheet like this alive, keeping the main architect going is the main focus, and if any of the posters who enjoy your work so much can help out with little things, or updating things, send to you and you can check it. I know sometimes that leads to more work and may be why you haven't already begun to delegate, but if you think it could help, let us know, I'm pretty sure the community has it in them to help out for something they care about.
Well, not to quibble, but: I have actually made proposals of this sort before, and requested that interested parties PM me; to date, I've received exactly 0 PMs offering assistance. The only independent development I'm aware of (since Darlal stopped working on the sheet, anyway) is Katherine's version with the 2.3 items in it, which, honestly, I probably should have looked over in more detail than I did; it came through while I was busy being sick and, as such, didn't get quite as much attention as it might have deserved.

I should note that that's totally fine, of course; I'm not trying to guilt anyone into volunteering. If people don't feel like working on it, that's totally understandable. I'm not complaining; I'm just making an observation that, for whatever reason, offers of help have not been particularly forthcoming.

However, it also should be noted that it's actually pretty hard to review changes made by other people. There's quite a bit of complexity in the sheet, and thousands upon thousands of cells of calculations. The only way I can even effectively verify my own changes is that I made the changes myself and thus know exactly what I messed with and where, which limits the number of things I have to check. I always perform certain modifications in the same way, which means that the number of places they can go wrong is limited. If, on the other hand, changes were made by other people, it's really impossible to know what all they may have made changes to and what implications it may have had. Fundamentally, if someone else wants to take up development on the sheet, it's going to need to get to a point where there is a person or people whom I can trust to get things more or less right without having to directly verify their changes. This is, admittedly, somewhat of a tall order, since the sheet is somewhat complicated and I'm not sure *I'd* be able to keep track of everything that was going on had I not written most of it myself.

And that, fundamentally, is one of the major problems with the sheet. I do think it's reasonably accurate and has a lot of nice features, but the cost of that is complexity; it takes a lot of time and effort to make even simple changes, which is why there tends to be quite a bit of time between each revision, and possibly the reason why other people, to date, have not been interested in working on it; this sheet is, quite simply, a pain in the you-know-where to update. It's the unfortunate reality of the situation, and one that can't really be remedied easily without sacrificing functionality or accuracy, neither of which I'm particularly inclined to do. Or, I should say, it's a limitation of spreadsheets that that's going to be the case; if written in an actual programming language, these effects would be somewhat reduced and it could probably be made more accurate, more functional, and easier to maintain. This is actually something I've thought about previously (I'm sure you can find repeated references to it in the prior posts within this thread), but the initial overhead of doing so has been, to date, sufficiently high that I haven't felt like working on it (see also: the above comments re: burnout). If, however, this is a project that people are interested in, and in particular if you're interested and have some coding experience, feel free to send me a PM (or otherwise contact me) and we can talk over the possibilities.

Anyway, long story short: I am not averse to offers of assistance in terms of maintaining the sheet, but in such a partnership it really would need to work toward a situation in which said maintainer took a certain level of responsibility for updating things with enough attention to detail that I don't need to review every single change, or it doesn't actually help matters much. This, coupled with the fairly high difficulty of maintaining things in the first place, provides a reasonable basis for why help has not been forthcoming to date, which is, as mentioned, totally understandable. As always, if you feel up to the challenge I would definitely like to hear from you, but I don't want anyone to feel obligated or pressured into doing so.`
#1410SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0♦ Aldriana
In random other news: it appears that the best rogue ranged weapon in the game - by a lot - is now a BoE epic. Swing by World of Raids and check out the screenshot of Spinesever, which trades 3 ap and 2 hit for 20 AP and 12 stamina relative to the previous best, Arcanite Steam-Pistol. By my count that's about an 8 AP upgrade offensively, with an extra 12 stamina to boot. Not too shabby.

Of course, if they don't retroactively change them... :P

Afaik there is no iLevel Calculator left that can propperly calculate sacrificed dps into the ilevel (not to say any remotely working ilevel calculator at all). Entering the stats on Spinesever into this Calculator results in an iLevel of 146 and since the calculated ilevels in most cases are quite some points lower than the in-game-ilevel i would guess that the real ilevel of Spinesever stats-wise is around 151-156. Of cause the dps doesn't fit into that ilevel range. Whereas the dps-range fits perfectly to the in-game-ilevel of the item itself (100) so it's quite possible that there has been made a n error in stats distribution on that thingie.

/edit: just playing around a little with the Calculator : seems like the +17 agility is cauing the huge stats-increase in ilevel. leave them out and everything else the same and you get an ilevel of around 109.

#1417SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0♦ Aldriana
I was talking to a friend last night and came up with a (crazy, but nevertheless) interesting idea. So, random crackpot theory time:

Observation 1: Spinesever has the look of an item designed specifically for rogues. The stat distribution is exactly what we'd want, and while the dps of it is fairly low, it's relatively slow for a ranged weapon leading to decent-sized Deadly Throws anyway.

Observation 2: Spinesever appears to be incredibly rare. After 3 days of patch, only one has been found on any server; now, I haven't actually run the statistics on this, but it seems to me that your average world-drop epic would appear a little more frequently than this when you look at all 300 servers.

Observation 3: The only known Spinesever was found in a pickpocketed lockbox, that is, from a source that only a rogue has access to, and that most rogues don't actually bother with.

Random crackpot theory: What if Spinesever *only* drops in pickpocketed lockboxes? It would explain the scarcity, and it would make a certain amount of sense if a rogue-optimized item came solely from a rogue-specific source, and might even justify the over-budget stats. I'd be a little surprised if this were the case, if for no other reason than because I would have expected it to be BoP were this true. But it still strikes me as an interesting idea, so I figured I'd share and see what other people thought.

Also, That is kind of a crackpot theory, but it almost works. Sadly, I doubt seriously that blizzard is this incredibly smart when it comes to itemization for, of all the classes, rogues. :\

I am the one who found it so I wanted to comment and set things straight.

To start off, Surma was my main as I raided extensively pre-TBC. After TBC I took some time off from raiding and never got back into it, so I switched to Merbale for PvP fun.

On 11/14 around 10:30-11am CST I found the item while grinding on 'Surma' near the Terrormasters in SMV. I use the popular PP and cheap shot macro. I looted 10 junk boxes during my 10-15 minute grind session. After I was done grinding, I started to open all the junk boxes hoping for healing potions. I was mindlessly opening them and looted the Spinesever.

In a year and a half of using the PP/CS macro all I had previously received from junkboxes was ONE green item.

This is a nice website. I've been lurking for quite some time.

I want to sell this thing, the amount of whispers and in game mails I've received is unbelievable.

I have the macro set-up as:
/#showtooltip Cheap Shot
/cast Pick Pocket
/stopcasting
/cast Cheap Shot

With the in game autoloot feature turned on, the only time I don't get all the items in the window is if my bags have gotten full. As a jewelcrafter (kit+gems = 4+slots), miner (ore + motes/primals = 6-10 slots), and rogue (poisons galore, flash powder, tools = 8 slots) with some PvP gear (8 slots), it seems like my 18-slot bags get full inordinately fast which has been only slightly improved by the Blinding Powder change.

#1428SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0Towbar
Long time reader, recently registered

I use this macro when farming:

#Showtooltip Sap
/cast Sap
/stopcasting
/script SetAutoLootDefault(1)
/cast Pick Pocket
/script SetAutoLootDefault(0)
/stopcasting

The sap is nice as it lets you get all the loot while your energy regens.

Would love one of these thrown weapons as I have had no luck so far regarding an Arcanite Steam Pistol.

#1433SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0Macblade
Another PP/CS option if you aren't getting everything with auto loot, might be to use the /castsequence command e.g.
I don't know that I've ever had a problem with it though.

/castsequence reset=0 Pick Pocket, Cheap Shot

hit it once to pick pocket and a second time to Cheap Shot.

A question about 5s/5r cycles. I'm a sword rogue and I've always heard of using 1s/5r or 2s/5r if you don't have 2/T4. Is 5s/5r for sword rogue? If so, can someone explain why you would want to wait and use 3 more CPs for a SnD?
#1434SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0
Edited onundefined		Arindelest
Originally Posted by Macblade

A question about 5s/5r cycles. I'm a sword rogue and I've always heard of using 1s/5r or 2s/5r if you don't have 2/T4. Is 5s/5r for sword rogue? If so, can someone explain why you would want to wait and use 3 more CPs for a SnD?
The basic idea behind any rotation is to keep Slice and Dice up 100% of the time while doing the maximum possible Rupture damage. The reason why you'd use any Xs/Yr rotation is that for your spec and gear, it optimally accomplishes both these goals.

That said, it depends what type of build exactly you're talking about.

As Combat Swords, 1s/5r is usually the norm with 2-piece Tier 4 (although it varies based on how much hit/haste you have for Combat Potency procs). Once you lose 2-piece Tier 4 the sheet will usually recommend 3.Xs/5r. As Aldriana put it so well in the first post of the thread, this means you can either "weave" 3 and 4 point Slice and Dices, or you can just do the next highest SnD, which will usually be 4. Of course you'd have to check the sheet with your specific gear and build put in.

As Hemo, combo point generation is a bit slower due to the lack of Combat Potency (even though Hemo only costs 35 energy). Therefore you'd want to a 5s/5r; however, you'd have to do one 4-point Rupture every so often because 5s/5r with this build is not hypothetically sustainable, and you also need to have the energy to use Blade Flurry.
Last edited by Arindelest : 11/17/07 at 11:01 PM.
#1435SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0♦ Aldriana
Originally Posted by Macblade
A question about 5s/5r cycles. I'm a sword rogue and I've always heard of using 1s/5r or 2s/5r if you don't have 2/T4. Is 5s/5r for sword rogue? If so, can someone explain why you would want to wait and use 3 more CPs for a SnD?
So, the reason one specifically doesn't use 1s5r or 2s5r as a sword rogue without 2/5 T4 is because you won't be able to keep up 100% SnD uptime, and that is, shall we say, very very bad, on the whole. Hence, you need to use a cycle long enough to keep SnD up; for most of us, that's either 3s5r or 4s5r.

Now, the next question is, why would one use 5s5r over one of those? Well, there's a couple answers to that question, all of which can reasonably be argued to be valid:

1) You shouldn't, 4s5r (or 3s5r, or whatever) is better.
2) Because 5s5r only deals trivially less damage (like, .2% or something), and some people find it easier to maintain, it's potentially worth using if you have responsibilities in a raid beyond optimizing your DPS.
3) 5s5r has more slack in it; if your cycle gets disrupted for any reason (Kaz'rogal War Stops you, Naj'entus throws up a shield causing you to pause DPS for a few seconds, Kael starts casting something that you need to kick, Magtheridon bounces you around, or even just simple bad luck on procs) 5s5r is less likely to drop SnD uptime due to the disruption than 4s5r or 3s5r.
4) What 5s5r fundamentally does relative to more compressed cycles is sacrifice some finisher damage for extra SS damage. 5s5r spends 0 net energy on finishers; a cycle like 3s5r on average spends 10 energy on finishers, which is 10 energy not being spend on Sinister Strikes. For most rogues, this tradeoff is worth it; however, at very high itemization levels, it's possible to get enough AP/Crit/Armor Penetration that the Sinister Strikes actually do more damage, such that 5s5r will actually do more damage.

And lastly, something I've been playing around with lately:
5) If you have Ashtongue Talisman of Lethality, the slack energy of 5s5r allows you to manipulate your cycles a little more than you can with a tighter cycle; you can, for instance, wait a few seconds after building up 5 combo points to let your energy tick up to ~60 before launching the next finisher; this allows more Sinister Strikes to be launched while the Ashtongue buff is up. Such manipulations are somewhat harder (though, admittedly, not totally impossible) with a tighter cycle.
#1436SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0Andeh
Originally Posted by Aldriana
And lastly, something I've been playing around with lately:
5) If you have Ashtongue Talisman of Lethality, the slack energy of 5s5r allows you to manipulate your cycles a little more than you can with a tighter cycle; you can, for instance, wait a few seconds after building up 5 combo points to let your energy tick up to ~60 before launching the next finisher; this allows more Sinister Strikes to be launched while the Ashtongue buff is up. Such manipulations are somewhat harder (though, admittedly, not totally impossible) with a tighter cycle.
I've actually been playing around with this myself as well, albeit going from a tight 3s/5r to 4s/5r. I haven't recorded any hard numbers, but my gut is that it is a significant increase. Not only from it being able to stack up a pool of energy to be burst out after finisher, but also due to getting an extra 20% for the buff. I'm considering moving up to a 5s/5r cycle for that reason, since it would give me a 100% chance for the buff, and I could get more SS's off while covered by it. Its like what you have to do as raid Mutilate with Find Weakness.
#1437SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0nelalas
Originally Posted by Aldriana
Such manipulations are somewhat harder (though, admittedly, not totally impossible) with a tighter cycle.
I can confirm that this is possible with a 1s/5r rotation though certainly not on every cycle. The cases where I have mostly been able to pull this "energy burst" off is typically when I cannot overwrite a rupture but still have some SnD time to spare. Since I have the Ashtongue trinket, I thought it better to save some energy while the last seconds of rupture tick off, refresh it (getting the trinket buff), renew my SnD, and launch some nasty sinister strike crits. Sadly, I finally broke my 2 piece-T4 bonus this week for T6 and will have to experiment with a longer cycle.

One question, though: is it also worth switching to 5s/5r, if you have the Ashtongue trinket, as to guarantee the buff after each SnD? Will the dps gained by increased trinket uptime outweigh the dps lost by less rupture uptime?
#1438SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0♦ Aldriana
Going from, say, 3s5r to 5s5r doesn't actually increase your Ashtongue uptime significantly; yes, you will get an Ashtongue proc on every SnD instead of only 60% of them; but your cycle is somewhat longer as well. Hence, neglecting any energy-queuing effects like the one discussed, the uptime works out to be very very close to the same. Hence, the only advantage of going to 5s5r is the greater ability to manipulate the cycle, which isn't modeled in the sheet (and probably never will be).

#1443SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0royaljester
Speaking of cycles, I'm currently ~t5 level with 1pc t6 and 1pc t4 still :\. I lost my 2pc t4 to get the t6 gloves, even the spreadsheet says it's a huge upgrade with the cycle difference, but it recommends a 3.4s5r. I was using that but noticing a lof of SnD overlap and usually having trouble keeping Rupture up all the time. I switched to a 1.2s5r (switching between 1 and 2 SnD's as needed) and see about 99% SnD uptime (less than a second of downtime, if at all) and 0 rupture overlap.

Is there a reason that I'm able to see somewhat tighter cycles in practice, but the sheet doesnt' offer it? Am I just that lucky that for the past week I've had amazing energy procs and thus able to run a tighter cycle?
#1444SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0♦ Aldriana
Originally Posted by mih
Bloodlust Brooch has 115ap, i think it should be 118 ^^ (115 is pre 2.1 itemchange)
Yeah, I noticed that while working on the sheet a week or two back; it'll be corrected in 0.9.

Originally Posted by royaljester
Speaking of cycles, I'm currently ~t5 level with 1pc t6 and 1pc t4 still :\. I lost my 2pc t4 to get the t6 gloves, even the spreadsheet says it's a huge upgrade with the cycle difference, but it recommends a 3.4s5r. I was using that but noticing a lof of SnD overlap and usually having trouble keeping Rupture up all the time. I switched to a 1.2s5r (switching between 1 and 2 SnD's as needed) and see about 99% SnD uptime (less than a second of downtime, if at all) and 0 rupture overlap.

Is there a reason that I'm able to see somewhat tighter cycles in practice, but the sheet doesnt' offer it? Am I just that lucky that for the past week I've had amazing energy procs and thus able to run a tighter cycle?
From a theoretical perspective, I don't see how 2s5r would be sustainable without 2/5 T4; consider:

A 2-point SnD with 3/3 Imp SnD lasts 17.4 seconds.

2s5r with 3/3 Ruthlessness requires, on average, 5.8 (7-2*.6) Sinister strikes to maintain; Assuming SS is never dodged, this requires, on average, 40*5.8 = 232 energy. Additionally, it requires an average of 15 energy to perform a 2-pt SnD. Hence, 247 energy is required per cycle.

Hence, to be sustainable, this requires that your energy regent exceed 247 per 17.4 seconds, or roughly 14.2 energy per second.

Natural regen is 10 energy per second; hence you need to generate 4.2 energy per second from other sources; ignoring Rod of the Sun King for the moment, the only real source for this is Combat Potency.

Combat Potency generates an average of 3 energy per hit; hence you need to average 1.4 OH hits per second. Even assuming that you are both hit and expertise capped, this still requires 1.4 attacks per second, or an average weapon speed of .71.

With the fastest possible OH (1.3) and 2/5 T6 on the SnD, even assuming 100% uptime on both mongoose enchants (unlikely), this still requires that one drop one's attack speed from .93 to .71 with haste effects; this requires an average of 467 haste rating - which I'm reasonably certain isn't possible.

Now, in short term situations - like, if you're getting chain-heroismed - this is possible. But in terms of a steady cycle that you can sustain without such internal factors? I'm not seeing it.
#1445SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0royaljester
Originally Posted by Aldriana
Yeah, I noticed that while working on the sheet a week or two back; it'll be corrected in 0.9.



From a theoretical perspective, I don't see how 2s5r would be sustainable without 2/5 T4; consider:

A 2-point SnD with 3/3 Imp SnD lasts 17.4 seconds.

2s5r with 3/3 Ruthlessness requires, on average, 5.8 (7-2*.6) Sinister strikes to maintain; Assuming SS is never dodged, this requires, on average, 40*5.8 = 232 energy. Additionally, it requires an average of 15 energy to perform a 2-pt SnD. Hence, 247 energy is required per cycle.

Hence, to be sustainable, this requires that your energy regent exceed 247 per 17.4 seconds, or roughly 14.2 energy per second.

Natural regen is 10 energy per second; hence you need to generate 4.2 energy per second from other sources; ignoring Rod of the Sun King for the moment, the only real source for this is Combat Potency.

Combat Potency generates an average of 3 energy per hit; hence you need to average 1.4 OH hits per second. Even assuming that you are both hit and expertise capped, this still requires 1.4 attacks per second, or an average weapon speed of .71.

With the fastest possible OH (1.3) and 2/5 T6 on the SnD, even assuming 100% uptime on both mongoose enchants (unlikely), this still requires that one drop one's attack speed from .93 to .71 with haste effects; this requires an average of 467 haste rating - which I'm reasonably certain isn't possible.

Now, in short term situations - like, if you're getting chain-heroismed - this is possible. But in terms of a steady cycle that you can sustain without such internal factors? I'm not seeing it.

As I said, it seemed odd to myself as well, losing an extra 3 secs on my SnD and I'm still able to maintain roughly the same cycle. I'll monitor it better this next hyjal/bt clear, but I'm fairly certain I saw little to no SnD/Rupture downtime.
#1446SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0Koosai
Since you have a DST I suspect that when it procs you get an excess of energy that allows you to keep the cycles going when you normally would not, also, BL or drums of battle would help out with the speed increase. If you are going to watch your uptimes, try and keep track of when your DST procs to see if that is where you are getting your extra energy.
#1447SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0royaljester

#1451SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0Ariose
Aldriana, I'm having trouble resolving these two facts on an intuitive level:

1. In a real world situation, switching from 3.x s/5r to 5s/5r amounts to a trivial amount of DPS lost.
2. In the model used in the spreadsheet, the 2pc T4 bonus is worth a substantial amount of AP (about 60 for me.)

If going from 3 sinister strikes to 5 isn't much of a loss, why is going from 3 sinister strikes to 1 a "noticeable" gain?
#1452SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0♦ Aldriana
A couple reasons:

1) The difference between 1 and 3 is larger than the difference between 3 and 5.
2) The difference between 5s5r and Xs5r tends to be smaller at higher itemization levels; most of the people here who are talking about Ashtongue Talisman cycles and the like tend to have T5-T6 level gear, and thus gain less benefit from Xs5r than someone at a T4 level of gear.
3) Even a "significant" difference can make a surprisingly small DPS difference.

An illustrative example: you refer to 2/5 T4 being about 60 AP for you. In my current gear (T5-T6 level gear), it scores only 15 AP. At a somewhat lower level of gear - say, the default gear in the 0.8 sheet - it's worth about 42 AP. Notice how as gear improves, the value of the benefit decreases.

Next, with the default gear, how much difference does that 40 AP actually make? Well, my listed DPS for 5s5r is 1480.49; with the 2/5 T4 bonus but otherwise identical stats, 1s5r would do 1499.44; hence, that 40 AP increase works out to about 19 actual DPS, or about 1.3%. So even a reasonably larger (say, 40 AP) bonus converts to little more than 1% change in real DPS. The differences we're talking aren't as large as one might think.

Thirdly, Xs5r (which recommends 3.4s5r) with my base gear comes out to 1486.91; notice that the damage difference between 1 and 3.4 is almost twice the damage difference from 3.4 to 5. So there's a bit of nonlinearity here as well.

So, with T5/early T6 gear, the difference between Xs5r and 5s5r is about 6 DPS, or .4%. I think it's fair to say that this is a "reasonably small difference". However, with the lower gear levels where 2/5 T4 tends to be more relevant, the difference between 1s5r can still be fairly significant (60 AP, as you say) despite this fact.

#1459SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0cooltaru
Originally Posted by banned
I added Vengeful Gladiator's Leather Helm and Grimgrin Faceguard to the spreadsheet and noticed that even if S3 helm get a higher offensive score, the dps is higher with the ZA helm.

I used the 0.8 OpenOffice version, everything in the spread sheet is at default setting except that I use Offensive value stats, and of course added the 2 items.

Gems for S3 helm: Relentless Earthstorm Diamond, 8hit
(1485,97 dps)

Gems for ZA helm: 16AP, 8hit, +agi/4hit
(1500.7 dps)


How come?
I have been studying the spreadsheet for the past few weeks, trying to learn the insides and outs to make my own changes for hemo/shadowstep/executioner/Items, etc for my own personal use.

I came across this error when I was comparing the Deathmantle Helm to the ZA helm. What's happening is even though you have selected the ZA helm that has no meta socket in it, it is still using the Meta Gem from the previous selection(i.e. RED).

To fix this, simply change the formula that is in cell F10 on the Talents_Equipment sheet from =IF(VLOOKUP(HelmEQ,ArmorStats,32,FALSE)>0,1,0) to =IF(VLOOKUP(HelmEQ,ArmorStats,31,FALSE)>0,1,0)

Hope that helps.

~Taru
#1460SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0banned
Originally Posted by cooltaru
To fix this, simply change the formula that is in cell F10 on the Talents_Equipment sheet from =IF(VLOOKUP(HelmEQ,ArmorStats,32,FALSE)>0,1,0) to =IF(VLOOKUP(HelmEQ,ArmorStats,31,FALSE)>0,1,0)
That seems to do the trick.

Thanks a lot!

#1484SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0Roguesen

#1485SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0enno
Originally Posted by Roguesen
How come shadow-panther (a very trusted rogue source) ranks it as one of the best raiding necks?

http://shadowpanther.net/armor-dps.htm


They don't, you're lookign at the wrong column: http://www.shadowpanther.net/armor-max.htm

Mind the small print at the bottom: DAEP: DPS-Oriented AEP formula for use in 5-man/leveling. MAEP: Maximum DPS AEP for use in maximizing raid DPS
#1486SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0♦ Aldriana
Originally Posted by Roguesen
How come shadow-panther (a very trusted rogue source) ranks it as one of the best raiding necks?

http://shadowpanther.net/armor-dps.htm
I think I object to the description of Shadowpanther as "very trusted". I think a more accurate term would be, perhaps, "widely used". In terms of accuracy, it's certainly better than some sources out there, but it can't really be considered a highly trusted source. As a quick reference guide it does fine, but in pretty much any circumstance when it differs from information on these forums, we're right and it's wrong.

One could, then, reasonably ask "why is it so widely used if it's not notably accurate?" Well, first, as a quick approximation when your gear is changing reasonably often and you don't feel like messing with a spreadsheet, it does fine - in that case, it does have it's place. Additionally, even were that not the case, there's certainly plenty of examples of widely trusted but vastly incorrect information out there. I can't tell you how many times I've been asked the question "if theorycraft says X, why does so-and-so from Nihilum do Y instead?" - to which the answer is, quite simply: because we're right and he's wrong. Or, as another example: back in the day, Ming had a nontrivial following in terms of rogue advice and strategy; however, 5 minutes examination of his derivation of an AEP system revealed that the fact that his recommendations were even close to right was more a matter of coincidence than any actual merit.

Anyway: I'm not saying that people shouldn't use Shadowpanther. I just encourage them to remember that it's only a rough estimate of the right answers, so people shouldn't be surprised when it disagrees with the more detailed examinations of the subject.
#1487SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0Mideci
WHile it's hard to add much to what Ald posted regarding Shadowpanther and Nihilum, it's true. Nihilum has exceptionally good WoW players and so they kill bosses faster than other people. If their first few guides are any indiciation, however, they have many bad theorycrafters who are simply wrong.

Because Nihilum achieves great things in WoW with their great players, they have many people emulate what they say is correct -- even when it isn't.

Playing well is going to improve your rogue dps with inferior gear more than getting better gear will -- unless you are skill capped.

I refer to Shadowpanther now and again for lists of items and such, but it's fairly easy to see how incorrect the information is. If you can find two items you own that are rated in different order by the rogue gear spreadsheet here and the shadowpanther list, go test them out in blasted lands and in a few raids. What you'll see is not only does the theorycraft back up the spreadsheets here over shadowpanther, but the reality does too.
#1488SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0dinesh
Rather than diss the Shadowpanther information (which I used for many, many months to help guide me in my gear selection up through T3), I'll point out that his rating system basically assigns static AEP values to each stat, then just does some simple math to total everything up. Then he provides three different sets of static weightings to approximate the benefits you might be getting playing three different playstyles.

The spreadsheets listed here, on the other hand, go to varying lengths to model the interaction between different stats and to calculate the relative "AEP" stats you should be using. They also, to different degrees, model cycles and other complex processes to better estimate true effect on your in-game DPS generation.

Nobody says the models are perfect, and a bad model might end up being less predictive than shadowpanther. Luckily, through lots of empirical testing and multiple eyeballs looking over the calculations, we're pretty certain the two sheets here are not "bad", and are hopefully pretty "good."

Summary: Trust the sheets here more than the shadowpanther estimates. But for people unwilling or unable to use and understand these sheets, shadowpanther is likely to be better than nothing. I certainly support him in his effort to help the community.
#1489SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0♦ Aldriana
Don't get me wrong: I don't think there's anything fundamentally wrong with his techniques; he scores stuff via equivalence points just like everyone else. It's just that the weightings there are a bit off for most people, such that the gear ordering, while decent, does have some places where I think the order is wrong. Is it better than nothing? Sure. As I said above, for those who don't want to spend the time on sheets, it's a perfectly reasonably place to be looking. But on the other hand, it does need to be remembered that it's not as accurate as some of the other sources available, which is why the question "Why does the spreadsheet say X while Shadowpanther says Y" is not the most productive of questions.
#1490SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0sylvestro

In terms of accuracy, it's certainly better than some sources out there, but it can't really be considered a highly trusted source. As a quick reference guide it does fine, but in pretty much any circumstance when it differs from information on these forums, we're right and it's wrong."

I use shadowpanther alot for general information dont get me wrong, but when you are searching for the theory behind the damage you do and/or trying to eek out 1 or 2 more dps from your already nearly maxed gear, here is where you will find the tools and information to do that, imo.
#1491SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0royaljester
Looking at the spreadsheet, I'm a bit mistified.

The World of Warcraft Armory

I'm sitting at 314 hit as of now, (I picked up the slayer's helm last night and added a 10hit gem to my gloves since we dont have the shifting shadowsong pattern yet :\). I know that trying to hitcap directly is pointless, but at the same time, having DST/WSC as my trinkets (both chance on hits, thus higher chance to proc with more hits), I would assume that adding hit isn't a bad thing.

My bamboozlement came from adding Mantle of Darkness and noticiing a DROP in dps over Swiftstrike shoulders. Compared, swiftstrike has 104~ap, .72%crit and 2.4% haste while mantle has 22 hit, 94ap and 1.49% crit. I guess I'm just amazed that 10ap and 2.4% haste > 22hit and +.77% crit. Even with kings, it only adds 3ap and .075% crit, not really adding to swiftstrike that much. This isn't really a HUGE issue since I won't have anyone going against me for the shoulders, but at the same time, why waste dkp on them if they aren't a true upgrade?
#1492SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0♦ Aldriana
Well, making the extraordinarily unscientific approximate that 1% hit, 1% crit, and 1% haste help one by roughly comparable amounts (which isn't precisely true, but as they're within 10% or so of each other it's close enough as to be illustrative): 22 hit is 1.40% hit, so 22 hit and .77 crit works out to about 2.2% benefit, versus 2.4% (from haste) and 10 AP. It certainly seems reasonable to me that the latter is better.

Fundamentally: hit gives you more white damage and more procs. Crit gives you more white and yellow damage. Haste gives you more white damage and more combat potency procs. All three are thus good, and, in equal percentage quantity, are in the same ballpark of quality. The reason why hit and haste are better than crit in practice is because it takes fewer points of them to make 1% benefit.

So, stated briefly: this is a classic case of "hit is good, but there are other stats which are also good, so one has to look at the tradeoffs". And in this case, both ballpark estimates and the detailed analysis of the spreadsheet seem to agree that Swiftstrike is better.
#1493SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0royaljester
I guess I didnt' see haste still being 1~1 with hit/agi just because of the haste nerf itself. But, if it is, then basically, swiftstrike is better by a small margain, and since I have already, might as well keep and not waste the DKP.
#1494SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0♦ Aldriana
Well, the haste nerf means you now get 2.4% haste instead of 3.6% haste for that amount of haste rating. But 1% haste is still 1% more white attacks (sort of). And if you look at the AP-equivalence table that's in the Roguecraft 101 table, you'll notice that while haste is now point-for-point a *bit* weaker than hit, it's still pretty good.

The real story here is the Mantle of Darkness just isn't very good.

#1496SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0♦ Aldriana
Couple of quick mechanics questions that arose while working on spreadsheet that I don't know the answers to off the top of my head. Any input you may be able to provide on the following would be helpful:

1) How does the new mace spec stack with Relentless Earthstorm Diamond?
2) I know it's been tested that Surprise Attacks stacks additively with Aggression and Opportunity; how do Aggression and Opportunity stack with each other? That is, is it (1+.06)*(1+.2)+.1, or (1+.06+.2+.1)?
3) Has the base dodge rate for boss mobs been determined? The best guess I've heard is 6.5%, and my own limited testing makes that seem plausible, but I haven't seen much formal testing of this. Does anyone know otherwise?
4) How much +attack speed does one typically actually gain from the Troll Racial in a sustained situation? I know it's 10% if you haven't taken any damage, but presumably sometimes you have taken more damage and thus get a larger speed increase. How often does this happen, and how large a speed boost do you get as a result? Ultimately I'll probably just make this an adjustable parameter, but what should the default be?

Thanks for the help.
#1497SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0♦ Vulajin
Originally Posted by Aldriana
Couple of quick mechanics questions that arose while working on spreadsheet that I don't know the answers to off the top of my head. Any input you may be able to provide on the following would be helpful:

1) How does the new mace spec stack with Relentless Earthstorm Diamond?
2) I know it's been tested that Surprise Attacks stacks additively with Aggression and Opportunity; how do Aggression and Opportunity stack with each other? That is, is it (1+.06)*(1+.2)+.1, or (1+.06+.2+.1)?
3) Has the base dodge rate for boss mobs been determined? The best guess I've heard is 6.5%, and my own limited testing makes that seem plausible, but I haven't seen much formal testing of this. Does anyone know otherwise?
4) How much +attack speed does one typically actually gain from the Troll Racial in a sustained situation? I know it's 10% if you haven't taken any damage, but presumably sometimes you have taken more damage and thus get a larger speed increase. How often does this happen, and how large a speed boost do you get as a result? Ultimately I'll probably just make this an adjustable parameter, but what should the default be?
1) I did some testing on the PTR and concluded that the difference between an additive combination of the two and a multiplicative combination is so miniscule, it'll be essentially impossible to determine which is the case under any real conditions. For simplicity, I modeled it as additive.
2) All of those talents stack additively.
3) I was asked in a PM recently to substantiate the 6.5% figure, and I really couldn't come up with much. There was a post late in the "weapon skill adjustment discussion" thread that contained parses which seemed to indicate dodge rates higher than 5.6% for bosses, but it's certainly nothing conclusive.
4) Just use 10%. It is far more likely you'll be at or near 100% when you use the ability, and I'm very willing to bet that any troll rogue who bides his time waiting to take damage before popping Berserking will have inferior results to one who uses the ability on cooldown regardless of health.
#1498SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0koaschten
4) Agree with Vulajin there, i will just pop it when ready, the steps are 10 20 30% where you gain 10% at 100-67%, 20% at 66-34% and 30% at 33-1%

And honestly, the only occasions i try to sync it with damage taken is Naj'entus when i don't cloak on purpose or at Teron when i soaked a shadowbolt and incinerate -> cloak+berserk

Troll Berserk is a great racial, but healers heal too fast to pop it conciously.

#1503SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0Dontmindme
Originally Posted by Aldriana
Couple of quick mechanics questions that arose while working on spreadsheet that I don't know the answers to off the top of my head. Any input you may be able to provide on the following would be helpful:

1) How does the new mace spec stack with Relentless Earthstorm Diamond?
2) I know it's been tested that Surprise Attacks stacks additively with Aggression and Opportunity; how do Aggression and Opportunity stack with each other? That is, is it (1+.06)*(1+.2)+.1, or (1+.06+.2+.1)?
3) Has the base dodge rate for boss mobs been determined? The best guess I've heard is 6.5%, and my own limited testing makes that seem plausible, but I haven't seen much formal testing of this. Does anyone know otherwise?
4) How much +attack speed does one typically actually gain from the Troll Racial in a sustained situation? I know it's 10% if you haven't taken any damage, but presumably sometimes you have taken more damage and thus get a larger speed increase. How often does this happen, and how large a speed boost do you get as a result? Ultimately I'll probably just make this an adjustable parameter, but what should the default be?

Thanks for the help.
They are additive (1+.06+.2+.1). It's not that hard to determine. You hit something with a low-range weapon, like a 2-4 damage sword or a 1-3 range dagger at a set AP. If you are hitting level 1 Young Ragged Wolves where crit kicks do 220, do the math, it's additive. Then again I was the one who came up with a way to determine if Weapon Skill was rounded or floored. Just need to set strict test conditions.

#1506SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0

Originally Posted by Aldriana
3) Has the base dodge rate for boss mobs been determined? The best guess I've heard is 6.5%, and my own limited testing makes that seem plausible, but I haven't seen much formal testing of this. Does anyone know otherwise?
I'm not really confidant in it's accuracy but, I've noticed about a 1% dodge rate vs. Boss level mobs for myself with 21 Expertise when looking over the past few weeks WWS reports. (5 from Human Racial, 10 from Talents, 6 from the Vashj belt) Which would put a boss at 6.25% Dodge from just the few boss reports recently. This is close enough to 6.5% that like you said, it looks plausible.

#1507SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0Melnor
While raiding last night I glanced down and moused over my Hemo tooltip and it said that hemo was applying 132% weapon damage along with the debuff. I was like, "when did they buff Hemo because I remember it was just a 125% bonus". Then it hit me, ohhh yea, 4pc T6 bonus. So I got curious and decided to check what the effect it had on the other abilites was. Backstab tooltip says 150% weapon damage normally, but with 4pc on, it said 159% weapon damage. Interesting I thought.. SS tooltip normally says 98 damage + weapon damage, but with 4pc on, it said 103-104 bonus damage. So that led me to another question, is the spreadsheet modeling the 4pc bonus in the way that blizzard is modeling it? It looks like blizzard is just adding 6% to whatever the base bonus the ability already has. The way I thought it would work would be that it would add 6% to your RNG roll for damage done, like if you Hemo'd normally for 2000 on a mob, then with the 4pc bonus, you would hit said mob for 2120. But with how Blizzard has modeled it, it seems like Backstab is receiving the most benefit from the set bonus and SS is getting the shaft. I was unable to test what it would have said for mutilate. I find it odd that Blizzard modeled it this way, but that could just be me.
#1508SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0• Aldriana
4-piece is currently being modeled as a flat x1.06 modifier after all other effects are calculated, which I believe is consistent with the real behavior.
#1509SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0Koosai
I seem to have found a bug in the 0.8 sheet. While I was playing around with a fist/sword spec I noticed that the APEP value listed for the hourglass of the unraveller goes *down* when I switch from 0/5 fist spec to 5/5 fist spec. Unless I'm crazy or mistaken shouldn't 5/5 give more crits which means more procs?

On a side note, I'm looking at Talon of Azshara and Talon of the Phoenix, is it sound logic to get which ever I can get first as they will be roughtly similiar when specced sword/sword or fist/sword?
#1510SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0• Aldriana
Originally Posted by Koosai
I seem to have found a bug in the 0.8 sheet. While I was playing around with a fist/sword spec I noticed that the APEP value listed for the hourglass of the unraveller goes *down* when I switch from 0/5 fist spec to 5/5 fist spec. Unless I'm crazy or mistaken shouldn't 5/5 give more crits which means more procs?
So, couple of points here:

1) The increase in procs from additional crit is reasonably minimal. With a 45 second cooldown on the effect, the difference between a 25% crit rate and a 30% crit rate is only about 5% uptime, and thus a reasonably small number of AP.

2) Increasing the amount of crit you have will decrease the relative value of additional crit, which will lower the value of the trinket somewhat.

Hence, it's at least plausible to me that such a thing as you describe might happen. However, since it does sound a bit odd, I will look into it over the weekend while I'm working on the sheet.

On a side note, I'm looking at Talon of Azshara and Talon of the Phoenix, is it sound logic to get which ever I can get first as they will be roughtly similiar when specced sword/sword or fist/sword?
Pretty much, yeah. Azshara is probably a bit better on the whole, but not enough to worry about; Phoenix is certainly better than any raid drop that you might otherwise be using.
#1511SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0royaljester
Originally Posted by Aldriana
4-piece is currently being modeled as a flat x1.06 modifier after all other effects are calculated, which I believe is consistent with the real behavior.

Is there a way to test that? According to the previous poster, he's noticing the change is being implemented on the tooltip, thus giving question to if it's being added before or after other modifiers. It seems sound logic that "increases dmg of ___ by 6%" would be before other modifiers...but maybe I'm wrong.
#1512SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0• Aldriana
If you're multiplying, it doesn't matter what order you do it in. I guess I'm not really seeing the concern:

Backstab: (150% + stuff)* 1.06 = 159% + other stuff, matching the tooltip
SS: damage + 98 * 1.06 = more damage + 103.88, which would be written as 103-104, matching tooltip
Hemo: 125% * 1.06 = 132.5% = 132-133%, again matching tooltip.

So what's the nature of the concern?

#1515SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0royaljester
I think the concern came from whether or not the addition of 6% more dmg came to just the SS/BS/Hemo itself, or was multiplied by the total outcome of dmg, which I guess (Haven't had math in a while) doesn't matter if they are all multiplicative.

I guess the faulty logic some of us are using was that if you added 6% dmg to just the 98 dmg, you got 103-104, which would be like adding +7 striking on your weapon, while if you added that 6% later, when the ss/bs/hemo hit for 2500, you'd get 2650, which would seem, on top, as more dmg. Again, we are most likely wrong, I just can't seem to remeber specifics/formulas.
#1516SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0• Aldriana
I'm pretty sure the 6% applies to weapon damage as well; it just doesn't show up in the tooltip since the SS tooltip doesn't say "does 100% of weapon damage plus..." it just says "does weapon damage plus" - so there's no way for it to automatically update to "does 106% of weapon damage plus". Again, I'd be shocked if it worked any other way; I think it's just an artifact of how the tooltip displays.

With the 4 piece bonus active, my Sinister Strikes averaged 416 damage while without the bonus, the Sinister Strikes caused 390 damage on average. #1532SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0Arindelest

#1533SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0◊ Shaker
Originally Posted by neg^
Seeing as you aren't combat daggers, 2pc T4 doesn't add that much for you. Go for T5 since each piece is quite a bit better then T4.
I just want to have it on record that this statement is HORRIBLY inaccurate. 2pc T4 is very strong for any build that's realistically being discussed in the endgame PVE scene. The statements above are very correct, it's hard to find a gearset that is stronger than 2pc T4 until you're at 4pc T5.

The sheet also does not use the values of the set bonuses in the specific upgrade columns - you need to look at the DPS estimate to see if you're losing DPS by breaking a set bonus.
#1534SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0royaljester
Originally Posted by Drunk
Ermm... what how does combat daggers benefit more from increased SnD uptime? It is all about shorter cycles getting Ruthlessness and Relentless Strikes proc more often?
To be honest, it should be quite clear.

Combat dagger cycles are usually 3s/5s/5r or 3s/3.4r or some variation. A combat sword cycle is usually 3s/5r and easily maintainable. A dagger rogue cycle, on the other hand, takes a lot longer to complete and maintain, thus getting rid of an extra SnD combo point would make it a more maintainable cycle. (When not using 2pc T4).

Having more SnD uptime will always benefit longer, more complex cycles more than shorter, easier to maintain cycles...Simple logic.
#1535SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0
Edited onundefined		◊ Shaker
Originally Posted by royaljester
To be honest, it should be quite clear.

Combat dagger cycles are usually 3s/5s/5r or 3s/3.4r or some variation. A combat sword cycle is usually 3s/5r and easily maintainable. A dagger rogue cycle, on the other hand, takes a lot longer to complete and maintain, thus getting rid of an extra SnD combo point would make it a more maintainable cycle. (When not using 2pc T4).

Having more SnD uptime will always benefit longer, more complex cycles more than shorter, easier to maintain cycles...Simple logic.
Actually, plugging my gear into the spreadsheet, then switching to an appropriate dagger spec (and using S2 daggers as compared to my S2 swords), I get the following values:

To drop the 2pc bonus, I switched my NB gloves to Grips of Deftness

~1423.63 (swords, w/ 2pc T4)
~1413.78 (swords w/o 2pc T4)
Value of Set bonus in the "Set Bonus Values" sheet - ~46.0

~1348.45 (daggers w/ 2pc T4)
~1344.1 (daggers w/o 2pc T4)
Value of Set bonus in the "Set Bonus Values" sheet - ~29.6

So no, it is NOT clear that it is better for combat daggers - in fact, it is QUITE clear to me that it is almost twice as good for combat swords.

The reason this is true is because the 2pc T4 adds a *static* 3s duration bonus to any SnD. Sword's tighter cycles utilize this in two ways - #1, they're faster cycles, so you get that 3s duration bonus more often. Also, they use smaller SnDs, so you get much bigger percentage increase. A 1pt SnD gives 4seconds bonus (from ~13s to ~17s), a 30% increase. A 5 pt SnD gives about 4.4 seconds (from 30.4 to 34.8), which is only a 15% increase.


Edit: more reasoning, clarifications
Last edited by Shaker : 12/03/07 at 12:59 PM.
#1536SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0roq
It is better for dagger rogues because we can have more rupture uptime. If you go back through this thread Ald points out some of the reason Dagger Rogues fall behind Sword Rogues. One of the reasons is they just can't keep rupture up nearly as much since 8 of their 13 Combo points goes to SnD. Running a 1s/3r with the t4 set bonus allows for more ruptures upping your DPS.
#1537SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0Macblade
Originally Posted by Koosai
Also, as a note it does from what I recall take the set bonus into account when reccomending upgrades. If it did you would never see anything as an upgrade for pretty much any piece that made your set bonus.
Unless this has been changed, I specifically remember Aldrianna saying that the sheet does NOT take into account set bonus when recommending specific item changes. I believe that he said it was for two reasons, one, it would be difficult to model. Two, it wouldn't be very accurate for gear recommendations because when it comes down to it, no piece of gear, on its own, would be worth breaking a set bonus as good as 2 peice T4 or 4 peice T5 etc. I believe that the idea is to collect two or three peices and then it will probably be worth swtiching over all at once. This is not something that the spreedsheet can do with gear recommendations though. You have to get the upgrades and then play around with the sheet and see when the individual upgrades that you have outweigh the value of a set bonus.
#1538SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0neg^
Originally Posted by Drunk
Ermm... what how does combat daggers benefit more from increased SnD uptime? It is all about shorter cycles getting Ruthlessness and Relentless Strikes proc more often?
With it daggers can move to 1s/3r which is as short as combat swords. For swords there really isn't that big of a difference in cycles, most of the time you end up refreshing snd early making the set bonus worth null(it's a choice of wasted energy, snd uptime or combopoints). As has been stated several times over in this thread.
#1539SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0• songster
Originally Posted by neg^
With it daggers can move to 1s/3r which is as short as combat swords.
...but wastes a lot of energy and still doesn't get good rupture uptime. Combat swords can do 1s/5r with 2 piece T4. That's as good as it gets. There really is no question that 2 piece T4 benefits swords/fists/maces much more than daggers. Shaker's last post gives very clear reasons why, and is correct.
#1540SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0• Aldriana
I'm not going to say what 1s5r isn't a better cycle than 1s3r, but in what possible way does 1s3r "waste energy"? And I'd also point out that 1s3r daggers gets better rupture uptime than 3s5r swords, so I'm not sure I buy the "doesn't get good uptime" argument either.

Fundamentally, the reason why some people advocate that 2/5 T4 is better for daggers is that it allows you to shift from a long, clunky, annoying cycle like 3s5s5r to a very short, compact cycle like 1s3r, with all the advantages of the shorter cycle and better DPS.

Now, trimming from 3.Xs5r to 1s5r certainly increases your DPS as well, but it doesn't have the fundamental effect of getting you out of a bad cycle into a good one like it does for daggers, which is why some people say it's a bigger deal for dagger rogues.
#1541SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0• songster
Originally Posted by Aldriana
I'm not going to say what 1s5r isn't a better cycle than 1s3r, but in what possible way does 1s3r "waste energy"?
Because a rupture costs the same irrespective of the number of combo points. You've spent 25 energy and only got 3 points' worth or rupture rather than 5. Call it wasting energy or what you will - the key point is that you pay the same and get less for it.
#1542SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0• Aldriana
One could make the same argument about the 1s5r cycle; a 1 point SnD costs more energy than a 5pt SnD. It's not a matter of "wasting" energy, it's a matter of spending it on something different. Fundamentally, what all compressed cycles do is trade SS/BS damage for finisher damage, and at most gear levels that's a worthwhile trade - although, at very high levels of gear, the fact that SS scales faster than Rupture means that you will reach a point where it's *not* a good tradeoff, and 5s5r passes 1s5r on damage output. Until you get to that point, however, describing "spending energy on a more damage-to-energy efficient move" as "wasting" energy is a bit misleading.
#1543SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0nelalas

It would be neat to see the results of our hit, expertise, and crit ratings in action when we swing a weapon. I suppose there would have to be two tables for both white damage and specials, and assumptions regarding positioning and target level. Just a thought.

#1544SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0• Aldriana
Originally Posted by nelalas
In some future version of the sheet, would it be possible to introduce a personalized Attack Table? Perhaps to the right of the Current/Optimal Hit cells or to replace these cells completely. It would be neat to see the results of our hit, expertise, and crit ratings in action when we swing a weapon. I suppose there would have to be two tables for both white damage and specials, and assumptions regarding positioning and target level. Just a thought.
I guess I'm not entirely certain what you mean by this, honestly. However, regardless of the specifics, I can safely say that this seems like a "nice-to-have" UI change, meaning that, like most of the other nice-to-have features, it's unlikely to find it's way into the spreadsheet anytime soon, as I'm more or less only doing the bare essentials now. If someone wants to take over UI work on the sheet and add some of these displays, we can work that out; but I have no plans to add such things myself.

Also, is Improved Sanctity Aura going to be included as a buff at some point? Yes we have a Ret Paladin and he is almost always in the melee group.
Um... maybe. As it's pretty easy to add it's a possibility; on the other hand since A) it doesn't change item valuations in any way shape or form, and B) Ret pallies are reasonably uncommon, it strikes me as not exactly the highest priority there is. All it would really mean is that the 5% of us that raid with a Ret Pally would have an accurate value for "Total DPS"... which, since this never was intended to be an accurate DPS sheet, strikes me as somewhat low in the priority list.
#1545SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.0◊ Shaker
