#1794SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2Ekto
In the Advanced Settings sheet, what does the cell marked as "fraction of incoming attacks where armor value conceivably matters" refer to? Same question for the cell above it about dodge/parry. Thanks.
#1795SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2• songster
Originally Posted by Aldriana
Hence, no cycle of this form can be optimal without 2/5 T4.
Question: is a cycle always the optimal solution?

Let's assume that I'm at a gear level where 3s/5r is the optimal cycle.

If I get a lot of CP procs back to back, it may well let me do something like 5s/5r/3e, even if that is not sustainable in the long run. Conversely, if I have a long streak of no CP procs, then if I don't have any "saved" energy, I won't able to compress my cycle down to 3s/5r, and I'll have to go for 4s/5r or even 5s/5r.

Now, what is my optimal strategy? Should I stick to a fixed cycle of 3s/5r, saving the energy from CP proc streaks to tide me over for long non-proc streaks? Or would I be better off using 5s/5r, and then tossing in an occasional Eviscerate once I've accumulated enough energy? In the latter case, what I'm essentially doing is trading in a little bit of rupture uptime for a higher percentage of Sinister Strike and the occasional Eviscerate.
#1796SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2• Aldriana
Originally Posted by SardonicJoe1
In the Advanced Settings sheet, what does the cell marked as "fraction of incoming attacks where armor value conceivably matters" refer to? Same question for the cell above it about dodge/parry. Thanks.
So, those are for estimating the relative value of defensive stats; in particular, they're needed to know how "good" dodge and armor are relative to armor. "Fraction of incoming attacks where armor value conceivably matters" refers to what fraction of the damage done to you is mitigated by armor in a useful way. For instance, mitigation is utterly useless on Archimonde, as if he hits you at all, it'll be for 20k+ damage, and you're gonna die no matter what your mitigation is - and the rest of his damage is all elemental. On the other hand, for, say, Hyjal trash, mitigation does matter, since you're mostly taking physical hits that are small enough that mitigation reduces your incoming damage in a useful way. Similarly, the dodge/parry cell is what fraction of incoming damage can be dodged or parried; hence, situations like "pulling aggro on Archimonde" or "getting bounced into a cleave on Magtheridon" are covered. Neither of these cells are used for offense calculations at all; they're purely for estimating how good stamina is versus agi, dodge, armor, etc.

Originally Posted by songster
Question: is a cycle always the optimal solution?

Let's assume that I'm at a gear level where 3s/5r is the optimal cycle.

If I get a lot of CP procs back to back, it may well let me do something like 5s/5r/3e, even if that is not sustainable in the long run. Conversely, if I have a long streak of no CP procs, then if I don't have any "saved" energy, I won't able to compress my cycle down to 3s/5r, and I'll have to go for 4s/5r or even 5s/5r.

Now, what is my optimal strategy? Should I stick to a fixed cycle of 3s/5r, saving the energy from CP proc streaks to tide me over for long non-proc streaks? Or would I be better off using 5s/5r, and then tossing in an occasional Eviscerate once I've accumulated enough energy? In the latter case, what I'm essentially doing is trading in a little bit of rupture uptime for a higher percentage of Sinister Strike and the occasional Eviscerate.
It's an interesting idea, to be sure, and, again, I haven't run the numbers to see, but my instinct is to say that the answer is no, for two reasons.

First, doing such a non-cycle in practice is actually quite hard. After you do your 5 point rupture and accumulate 3 more CPs, at that point you need to decide whether you have enough energy/time to use those 3 CPs towards an Eviscerate and still have enough time to get 5 more for the SnD. The problem is, you're making this decision 10-15 seconds before the end of the cycle, and you don't know what your combat potency luck is going to look like for that time. Hence, I suspect doing such a rotation would be very error prone in practice, and you'd end up misjudging fairly regularly and needing to improvise something to get back into your cycle.

It might be a little better to plan something like 5s5r5e3s5s5r - that is, build up to 5 CPs, see how much time you have left, and the either do the regular SnD a full Eviscerate and a small SnD after before building back up to the usual cycle... but even this seems unlikely to be a clear winner.

Second, it's not clear to me that the better use of such surges in energy regen isn't to gain higher rupture uptime; with 3s5r, no matter how lucky you get, you can always rupture pretty much as soon as you need to; your previous rupture will always have ticked of. So if I did get lucky with procs, I'd be inclined to use it to complete a cycle in 17 seconds instead of 22 to get higher Rupture uptime.

Fundamentally, though, it is something we should probably investigate at some point. It's sort of hard to model due to all the decisionmaking that needs to occur, but I'm sure we can whip something up.
#1797SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2Koosai
While we are whimsical what ifs, I recently ran a Kara with one tank, a pally. During the run I was thinking about the proper finisher to use. Since there was no warrior in the raid I could use Expose armor, or I could evis/rupture on the bosses that let me rupture. I believe I ended up using Expose armor on the bosses that I couldn't rupture on and Rupture otherwise. Though that was mostly because I noticed that I was not as far ahead on damage while I was using Expose Armor. In that situation does that seem reasonable? I would imagine that the extra armor pen would help me, the other rogue, and the hunter more than me using evis/rupture... but I'm not sure.
#1798SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2todemax
I did some calculations some time ago at that gear level, and the conclusion was pretty much that in the case of no warriors in the raid, expose armor is viable if 2 additional dps'ers are in the raid, while only 1 additional is required if you have improved expose armor. It was done pretty roughly in the dps sheet by removing the finisher damage while reducing the boss armor, but I don't have any hard math at hand at the moment sorry.
#1799SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2• Latito
I've actually had some experience with Expose Armor recently and hopefully this helps...
Basically, my guild uses a druid MT on a lot of bosses. We have a single prot warrior in the raid, and he is less geared than the druid. Obviously the prot warrior tanks stuff like RoS and Illidan, but a bulk of the other bosses are druid-tanked. Because of this, and a fairly melee-heavy raid (6-7 melee and a hunter or 2) I figured I'd try out Imp Expose armor.

First, with EA you are REQUIRED to use a 5-point finisher. Using less than 5-point makes the EA reduce less damage, it doesn't affect the duration. EA is always 30 seconds long. So you have a few options.. 3s/5e, 5s/5e, 5s/5e/Xr. Doing 3s/5e doesn't actually help, since EA and SnD are up 100% of the time with 5s/5e anyways. All it does is make your SnD cost 10 energy (Effectively, long-term). Not to mention it is more suseptable to bad CP streaks resulting in one or the other falling off. 5s/5e/3r isn't sustainable. 5s lasts ~30 seconds (round down a bit since you refresh just BEFORE it falls). In 30 seconds you gain roughly 390 energy from Combat Potency (OH at an average of 1.0 speed, 15 energy per 5 seconds). The cycle requires 13 CP, minus 3 * 0.6 which you get from finishers. The SnD and EA are free, Rupture costs 10 energy (60% chance its free, 40% chance its 25 energy). This works out to ~11 finishers * 40 energy + 10 energy for finishers. 450 energy.. you gain 390. Not sustainable. Not to mention, a 3point rupture every 30 seconds just really isn't a huge dps increase.

Therefore, 5s/5e is the preferred rotation (unless someone can find something better?). Its super easy, can be done in BAD gear (1.5 spd OH, no haste, ~200 hit). With a 1.4spd OH, static haste and 2pc T6 and 350 hit.. I would have to be unconscious to fail at keeping both up 100% of the time.

Now, for DPS estimates. The current spreadsheet puts me at 1875 DPS with the set of buffs I had last week on Teron. Thats for 3s/5r. If I drop to 2/5 (instead of 4/5) Vile poisons, I get a 5s/5r dps of 1854. Of that, 83 dps is attributed to Rupture, so take that away and I'm at 1771 dps. I added a new buff, Imp Expose Armor and set it up, turned it on and turned Sunder x5 off. I now have a 5s/5r dps of 1944. Subtract the 83 dps I from rupture to get 1861 dps.

So, 1861 dps, compared to 1875 (if I was spec'd 4/5 vile and let the warrior sunder). 14 dps loss personally, but every melee in the raid goes up by ~75-80 dps. The prot warrior will go from dps'ing and sundering to just dps'ing.. I'm sure he'll gain back at least the 14 dps I lost by not having to use sunder.

On Teron this week I ended up at 1793 dps doing that. It was a loooong kill due to 23-manning it (don't ask), short 2 dps and getting mostly dps'ers ghosted. Aside from 1 BL in 6 min instead of 1 per 10 min.. nearly every CD was at approx the average uptime rate. Not sure what I did wrong, but 96% of my theoretical isn't *too* bad I guess.
#1800SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2• Aldriana
So, this isn't conclusive, to be sure, but: I just whipped up some approximations for a nonsundered opponent. For the Rupture cycle, I'm using my regular optimal cycle, Xs5r. For the Expose cycle (which I will denote as 5s5a, as "e" is taken for Eviscerate/Envenom), I'm using the numbers from the 5s cycle, with the armor of the boss manually lowered by 2050. Since neither a 5 point SnD nor a 5 point Expose uses any energy, and 5s5a gives both 100% SnD uptime and 100% Expose uptime, so this should be a pretty valid approximation.

I also cut down the buff level to be more consistent with a 10 man raid with no warrior present (in particular, only one pally buff and no battle shout).

So, the numbers:

With 7700 base armor:
Xs5r: 1284 DPS
5s5a: 1329 DPS

With 6200 base armor:
Xs5r: 1391 DPS
5s5a: 1468 DPS

Now, admittedly, this is for only one set of gear, and it's not going to be 100% accurate, but: off the top of my head, Expose does seem to be generally better even for personal DPS and thus certainly better for raid DPS in unsundered situations.
#1801SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2• Latito
Oh, also.. a while ago during one of my Dire Maul sessions I decided to test some cycles a bit.

I did 10-minute runs, using BF 5x and AR twice each test. I watched my dps on Recount and after 6-7 min it never jumped around more than 10-15 dps. Obviously this is with NO buffs, and no other debuffs on the boss. When doing 3s/5r I was hovering around 1200 dps, when doing 5s/5a (using Ald's abbreviation now) I got 1280 dps. Certainly a difference large enough to rule out some streaks, considering these were over 10 minute periods as well, not just 2-3. This was against the Gorduk Spirits in DM North, can't remember what their armor was at, but its likely around 3-4k base. That was without Imp EA.


So while that is more "anecdotal" evidence - it does match reasonably close to Ald's previous post where non-Imp EA is a personal dps increase over Rupture when no warrior is present. By the math in my first post, Imp EA is a raid-dps increase over Sunder. That said, you CANNOT EA on a boss when a prot warrior is tanking, it just kills threat too much. For druid/pally tanks however, it is worthwhile.
#1802SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2
Edited onundefined		• songster
Originally Posted by Latito
5s/5e/3r isn't sustainable. [...]. Not to mention, a 3point rupture every 30 seconds just really isn't a huge dps increase. Therefore, 5s/5e is the preferred rotation (unless someone can find something better?).
Any DPS increase is better than zero. So you won't have enough energy for a rupture on every cycle - no reason not to throw in a rupture when you do have the spare energy. So your effective cycle could end up something like 5s/5e/5s/5e/3r. Or even longer if that's still not quite workable. I'm honestly beginning to think that the mindset of "must find a cycle at all costs" is going to end up with bad rogues making stupid decisions. No cycle will ever perfectly match your energy income. You can either use the slack energy (and thus not use a perfect cycle, shock horror!) or waste it. It shouldn't take pages of theorycraft to work out which of those two is a better option!

Edited to add: The fact that Expose armor is a better finisher than Rupture on an unsundered mob should not be news to anyone reading this thread. In a raid situation Improved Expose is better than a full stack of sunders for raid dps. However, in practice you can't use it if you have a prot warrior in the raid. Even if the prot warrior isn't tanking, their personal DPS depends on the Sunder stack, which reduces or wipes out the net raid gain.
Last edited by songster : 01/13/08 at 6:26 AM.
#1803SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2• Latito
Fair enough. Agreed, any dps increase is better than zero. That said, a cycle such as that still requires you to do "5s/5a/3r/5s" at one point in the rotation. Essentially, you must get 13 combo points within 30 seconds. Saving energy and dropping the first 5s while you have ~70 energy *should* likely allow this to happen.. but you could get unlucky of the next 30 seconds with ruthlessness and combat potency, thus dropping SnD (and likely EA 8-10 sec later also). The MARGINAL dps increase of an extra 3-point rupture every minute just doesn't seem worth the risk. We could do the math I guess and see what % chance you have of being able to pull off that sequence, figure out the dps loss if you lose SnD for X amount of time and see if that potential dps loss * chance to happen is less or greater than the extra dmg from rupture.

Agreed, cycles are never perfect - I sometimes find myself needed to cut out a rupture set from my cycles to keep SnD up and adapting to circumstances is what keeps a rogues dps more consistant, as opposed to flopping around and being kinda streaky. It is a balancing act,


On the topic of EA usage.. clearly it was news to Nanomann, and even Ald and myself wanted to double check. It makes sense, but its worth checking. I'm sure there is some level of high AP, low hit, low crit, no haste or arm Pen which makes Rupture better than EA on an unsundered mob. Likely its so damn high that the set of gear which achieves that does not exist, but still.

In a raid situation, I'm not sure how the prot warriors dps is affected. I realize they would no longer be able to Devastate, is this one of their primary moves while dps'ing, or do they pretend to be Fury and just HS/WW? Perhaps some insight from the prot warrior thread would be good. Good thought - it was something I hadn't considered.
#1804SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2• Aldriana
Originally Posted by songster
Any DPS increase is better than zero. So you won't have enough energy for a rupture on every cycle - no reason not to throw in a rupture when you do have the spare energy. So your effective cycle could end up something like 5s/5e/5s/5e/3r. Or even longer if that's still not quite workable. I'm honestly beginning to think that the mindset of "must find a cycle at all costs" is going to end up with bad rogues making stupid decisions. No cycle will ever perfectly match your energy income. You can either use the slack energy (and thus not use a perfect cycle, shock horror!) or waste it. It shouldn't take pages of theorycraft to work out which of those two is a better option!
I don't see that it's quite that clear cut. First off, the fact that your energy bar is bigger than the amount of energy needed for any particular move gives you some ability to store up energy. The cycles produced by this sheet are average cycles; during some SnDs you'll generate more energy than average, and in some you'll generate less; hence, in order to keep SnD from dropping during low-energy cycles, you need to save up energy (to the extent you can) during surplus energy cycles. Now, this isn't 100% possible, of course - your energy bar is only so big, so there's only so much error you can absorb; this means two things in practice. First, sometimes you will generate more energy than you can store, and thus need to "waste" some SnD uptime by shortcutting the cycle; second, to make sure that you (almost) never have a drought so large than SnD drops, you need to use a cycle slightly longer than the long-term average case to give you a cushion against SnD gaps - which, in turn, leads to more wasted SnD uptime.

So, fundamentally, yes, one tends to have - depending on how you look at it - either surplus energy or surplus SnD uptime relative to the ideal cycle. And, from a purely abstract perspective, it would be beneficial to use this to generate a little extra DPS.

The problem is, it's not always possible to do so. First, there's the simple problem that you need to make decisions at intermediate locations in the cycle - that is, if you try to squeeze an extra finisher in before the SnD, you don't know if Ruthlessness will proc; you don't know how many Combat Potency procs you're going to get in the last 10 seconds of your cycle; if it's not a 5-point finisher, you don't know if Relentless Strikes will proc; and so on. Hence, you are still making a decision with some variance to it, and to avoid having SnD drop (or having to do a very small SnD followed by some ad hoc cycling to bootstrap back up to a normal-sized SnD, which is almost always bad) you still need to allow yourself a cushion - which brings us back to the aforementioned issues. So while you may be able to reduce the amount of wasted SnD uptime through such tactics, you will never eliminate in entirely.

Additionally, there's the fact that in many circumstances, just doing an extra SS or burning the SnD uptime is actually optimal. Determining which ad hoc cycle components actually prove worthwhile is a problem that I don't think most people have a good appreciation for. For instance, it has been suggested that dropping a 3-pt Eviscerate during high energy cycles of 5s5r might be better than doing the standard 3s5r. Now, my question is: is the damage gained by the higher energy efficiency of an occasional 3 point Eviscerate enough to offset the damage lost to reduced Rupture uptime? I would argue that the answer is almost always no; the overall energy efficiency of the cycle element is not enough larger to warrant this approach.

And that, I think, is going to be the key to analyzing these; the notion of energy efficiency of cycle elements. The concept of energy efficiency of individual moves is a fairly standard one by now; the trick is, it doesn't really tell the whole story. What you really want to know is the energy efficiency of a combination moves. Let me give a concrete example of what I mean.

Lets compute the energy efficiency of performing a single iteration of 3s5r. This requires 6.8 Sinister Strikes and does the damage of one rupture. Hence, the total energy expended is (roughly) 40 * 6.8 + 10 (for the chance Relentless Strikes does not proc), and the total damage is 6.8 times the damage of a SS plus the damage of one rupture. Working this out for the information currently in my spreadsheet gives an energy efficiency of about 37.76 damage per energy. Note that we're ignoring the damage contribution of the SnD; for purposes of computing components of ad hoc cycles, we're assuming that due to abnormally high energy regen or whatever, we're able to do this component with 100% SnD uptime; hence, that damage will just subtract out evenly accross all builds.

Now, if we compute the energy efficiency of 5s5r, we find that it's only 37.23, while the energy efficiency of a 5s5r3e component is 37.84.

So: what we learn from this is that a 5s5r3e element is actually more energy efficient than 3s5r (though barely) - however, it is only more efficient by .08 damage per energy, while 5s5r is .53 DPE less efficient; hence, roughly 87% of energy would need to be spent of 5s5r3e cycle elements and only 13% on 5s5r cycle elements in order for the ad hoc cycle to come out ahead - which is clearly not sustainable. So we find that 5s5r with adhoc 5s5r3e is inferior to 3s5r.

Now, I can easily imagine circumstances - gear combinations and the like - where this will not be true; I'm sure there are times that 5s5r with adhoc 5s5r3e is better. The problem is, this level of analysis is not something you can do on the fly; hence, making cycles up as you go is, in most cases, likely inferior. And while I'm sure it would be possible to understand your gear and energy tradeoffs well enough to figure out for yourself when you should do what, it's most defenitely an advanced technique that only the most knowledgeable and experienced of rogues would want to attempt; it's certainly nothing I'd recommend to the average spreadsheet user.

Fundamentally, I guess my point is this: the relative value of Rogue finishers are such that I don't see that a compelling case can be made to do ad hoc cycles; in the vast majority of cases, XsYr type cycles will be optimal for appropriate choice of X and Y and good energy management. If at some point Eviscerate/Envenom/whatever becomes competitive, ad hoc cycles might be sufficiently good to revisit; but I don't think that's the case right now.

Edited to add: The fact that Expose armor is a better finisher than Rupture on an unsundered mob should not be news to anyone reading this thread. In a raid situation Improved Expose is better than a full stack of sunders for raid dps. However, in practice you can't use it if you have a prot warrior in the raid. Even if the prot warrior isn't tanking, their personal DPS depends on the Sunder stack, which reduces or wipes out the net raid gain.
If the warrior is tanking, you certainly can't expose; however, the damage that a prot warrior gains from sundering isn't actually that large; even assuming they're spamming Devastate for DPS every cooldown, they're only going to gain 175 damage every 1.5 seconds (further modified by crit chance, hit chance, and armor reduction) - or something on the order of 120 DPS. And I can almost guarantee you that the damage gained over the raid by going from 2600 reduction (Sunders) to 3075 (Imp Expose) is enough to offset both that and the ~100 DPS the Exposing rogue would be doing with Rupture. So if one is in a guild that regularly has feral druids tanking raid bosses, it might be worth speccing Imp Expose, as it is almost certainly worth using whenever a warrior is not tanking, even if there is a prot warrior or two DPSing.

Edit: I'm assuming, of course, that the warrior can still Devastate, which I believe is true; the Sunder just doesn't go off. If this isn't true, the answer may be different... but I suspect the 475 extra armor pen is still enough to cover it, at least in a 25 man.
#1805SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2• songster
Originally Posted by Aldriana
I don't see that it's quite that clear cut.
It is in the case I was talking about - keeping up Expose Armor. A 5s/5exp cycle gives you 100% uptime on both and some spare energy. You have three options for the extra energy.

1) Waste it completely by cutting the S'n'D or the EA short
2) Use it for extra Sinister Strikes, and waste the combo points
3) Use it for extra Sinister Strikes and an occasional rupture.

As long as you don't drop below 100% uptime for S'n'D and EA, solution (3) is clearly the best option, since Rupture has better energy efficiency than Sinister Strike. In practice it's difficult to achieve (3), since an energy buffer of 100 doesn't let you save up enough spare energy to be sure of dropping a sensible-sized rupture.

The 5s/5expose cycle costs 352 energy (8.8 sinister strikes, free finishers), and your expected energy income for a 30 second cycle is ~390, i.e. you have one spare sinister strike per cycle. So if you're thinking in "cycle" terms, that's a 5s/5expose cycle with an extra SS inserted somewhere at random in each cycle.

However, I think the better strategy is to save up as much of the energy as you can, right up to the point where you're about to tick over. Then you spend the extra energy all at once - i.e. rather than doing one extra SS per cycle, you do 2 or 3 extra SS every second or third cycle. If you happen to get lucky with CP procs at that point, it will allow you to drop in a small rupture (better energy efficiency than SS), while if you don't get lucky, it's not wasting anything more than you otherwise would.

Question: What's the smallest rupture that has better DPE than a SS?
#1806SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2◊ Vulajin
According to my spreadsheet, a 2-CP Rupture or above will be superior DPE to an SS, but only by ~11. Since this figure doesn't account for Relentless Strikes energy regen, I'd say it's still not worthwhile to perform a 2-CP Rupture, especially since a 2-CP Rupture only gains 2% of your AP per tick, whereas 3 and above all gain 3% per tick. So the smallest worthwhile Rupture is essentially 3-CP.
#1807SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2• Aldriana
Originally Posted by songster
It is in the case I was talking about - keeping up Expose Armor. A 5s/5exp cycle gives you 100% uptime on both and some spare energy. You have three options for the extra energy.

<snip>
Agreed, for the 5s5a case, weaving the occasional rupture is probably worthwhile if you can do it. I was referring more to the line

I'm honestly beginning to think that the mindset of "must find a cycle at all costs" is going to end up with bad rogues making stupid decisions. No cycle will ever perfectly match your energy income. You can either use the slack energy (and thus not use a perfect cycle, shock horror!) or waste it. It shouldn't take pages of theorycraft to work out which of those two is a better option!
Fundamentally: yes, there are times (such as 5s5a cycles) where it usually makes sense to weave in something if you can. But there's also a *lot* of circumstances where it doesn't, so on the whole I think cycles are a good thing - I believe it is the exception and not the rule when weaved cycles are able to beat static cycles.
#1808SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2Ekto
I have a question about a specific cell in the spreadsheet: cell G74 on the Xs5r worksheet. I assumed that each column on this sheet calculates the dps when you add one more of the relevant combat stat. So, for example, column G calculates your dps when you add 1 more hit rating to your stats. If that is the case, shouldn't the last term in G74 have a minus sign, NOT a plus sign. The plus sign increases your miss chance and, thus, calculates your dps if you were to LOSE one hit rating. There is a similar concern with cell I75. I did not check the other worksheets for this possible error, so you may need to fix those, too, if I understand this worksheet correctly.
#1809SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2• Aldriana
Adding and removing one of each stats should have more or less the same effect; what you're really attempting to do is approximate the derivative of the function at that point, for which either endpoint approximation is equally valid. For maximum accuracy, we should really be doing a midpoint approximation, but as that would take 2 columns per stat as opposed to one, I figured endpoint approximations were probably sufficient. And as either endpoint is equally good, I can use whichever is more convenient for the particular stat. In the specific case of the cells you mention (which will be the same in all calc sheets) I elected to compare by removing one hit rather than adding one (and doing it in G74 and I75 instead of G7 and I11) to work around the hit cap. Subtracting 13/205 in G74/I75 would risk giving a negative hit score for people at the hit cap, which may potentially cause odd results. Hence, I add in instead so the hit stays in the valid range. Since the actual comparisons are performed against the absolute value of the difference anyway, it all works out in the end.

Note that most of the procs/set bonuses do this sort of thing as well: if you have the buff, they remove it, and if you don't have the buff, they add it. Hence, at any given time, some are being scored by "subtracting" and some by "adding". But as both are equally valid, this is fine.
#1810SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2
Edited onundefined		Ekto
Originally Posted by Aldriana
Adding and removing one of each stats should have more or less the same effect; what you're really attempting to do is approximate the derivative of the function at that point, for which either endpoint approximation is equally valid. For maximum accuracy, we should really be doing a midpoint approximation, but as that would take 2 columns per stat as opposed to one, I figured endpoint approximations were probably sufficient. And as either endpoint is equally good, I can use whichever is more convenient for the particular stat. In the specific case of the cells you mention (which will be the same in all calc sheets) I elected to compare by removing one hit rather than adding one (and doing it in G74 and I75 instead of G7 and I11) to work around the hit cap. Subtracting 13/205 in G74/I75 would risk giving a negative hit score for people at the hit cap, which may potentially cause odd results. Hence, I add in instead so the hit stays in the valid range. Since the actual comparisons are performed against the absolute value of the difference anyway, it all works out in the end.

Note that most of the procs/set bonuses do this sort of thing as well: if you have the buff, they remove it, and if you don't have the buff, they add it. Hence, at any given time, some are being scored by "subtracting" and some by "adding". But as both are equally valid, this is fine.
ah ok, makes sense then.

In my own spreadsheet, I too have had to deal with the less than aesthetic ways of dealing with evaluating a function at different points. Is there no way in Excel to define some functions or functions in terms of letters and then just evaluate the functions for given sets of data points?

For example, something like "LET(f = 1-h/1577-.0025*e/3.924-.01*p)" where f is supposed to be your chance to miss, with h your hit rating, e your expertise rating, and p your rank of precision (and LET is some Excel function I made up that ostensibly defines f algebraically). Then in some cell specify a range of cells to represent the desired values of h, e, and p. and then in another cell evaluate f for the given data. I suppose that this would require Excel to have some sort of CAS built in, and so if it's not possible, I would understand.

Thanks for the usual speedy response.

[Edit] For my own gear, the dps difference between +1AP and base stats on the Xs5r is ~0.308. The (absolute) dps difference between -1hit and my base stats on the Xs5r worksheet is ~0.795, giving a relative value of hit to AP of 2.584. but the dps difference between +1hit and my base stats on the same worksheet is ~0.117, giving a relative value to AP of 0.381.

Now I know that the sheet is not meant to give a static AEP table, but an AEP table for each data point corresponding to each possible combination of stats. But if the plus/minus signs in cell G74 and I75 are supposed to be equally valid, they should give (at least approximately) the same AEP for a given set of data. Going from 2.584 to 0.381 is quite a difference.
Last edited by Ekto : 01/15/08 at 6:05 PM.
#1811SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2• Aldriana
I think there are ways to do such things - in fact, I'm pretty sure the Rogue DPS sheet does them. The problem is that they all involve macros, which starts to cause issues with OO compatability and the like (not to mention being well beyond my knowledge of Excel) which is why I chose not to use them. It's one of the limitations of the spreadsheet format - which brings us back to the oft-mentioned "write this in a real programming language" point (which I'm working on, I swear). Basically, doing things in a spreadsheet makes the UI work a lot simpler but it does put some fairly heavy limitations on your ability to evaluate certain things.
#1812SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2Bluefish
I'm having trouble convincing the Balance Druid community here on EJ that Imp Faerie Fire is worth spec'ing into. The Druid themself loses a significant amount of either DPS, threat reduction, or sustainability to spec into it, but according to the Gear Sheet, the benefits are pretty crazy for those that aren't hit-capped. I show 1491 DPS with WF / LotP / Imp BS / Might / Kings / Drums / Enh Shaman, no CoR. When I compare each of these buffs to Imp FF, it comes out ahead of Might, Windfury, even LotP! Can you confirm that the Gear Sheet is properly modeling Imp FF? If so, could you possibly stop by the Balance thread and let them know?
#1813SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2• Aldriana
Well, the thing to be careful about is that while Imp FF does come in ahead of those things, the marginal difference between FF and Imp FF is somewhat smaller.

Using, for instance, the stat weightings Vulajin posted in the Roguecraft 101 thread:

Imp FF gives 3% hit ~= 47 hit rating ~= 2.3 * 47 = 108 EAP, plus 610 armor reduction = 610 * .29 = 177 EAP, for a total of 285 AP - which is more than Blessing of Might, almost as much as Battle Shout, and more than the 5 * 22.1 * 1.75 = 193 EAP one gets from Leader of the Pack.

The thing to be careful about it: regular Faerie Fire already gives the armor pen, so speccing into Imp FF gives roughly 108 AP *additional* benefit beyond what we'd otherwise get from the druid. Hence, each talent point gives something on the order of 36 AP benefit per rogue, which, in practice, means about 11 DPS per rogue per point. So if you have 3 rogues, it gives a benefit of roughly 33 DPS per point, or about 100 DPS for all 3 points... plus whatever it does for the hunters, dps warriors, enhancement shaman, etc. Also note that if you're tank isn't hit capped (and a lot of tanks aren't) it also significantly increases the tank's aggro.

So, long story short: the incremental benefit from Imp FF is not quite as large as some of the others you list; however, it's still a very helpful talent for all your melee DPS and probably some of your tanks as well. I can easily see 3/3 Imp FF increasing the tank's aggro by ~4% and increasing raid DPS by ~200. How that compares to the other talents you could be taking, I couldn't say... but it's certainly a very respectable talent from the perspective of the rest of the raid.
#1814SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2royaljester
And let's be honest, balacne druids aren't there for their amazing dps and sustainablity. They are there for the 5% spell crit (amazing for pallies/mages omg) and possibly the imp FF. I think the biggest benefit comes from being able to reitemize your gear with that druid using some off peices with less hit and stack more ap/crit. I know hunters are able to drop talent points and get some other talents.

If the druid is worried about losing pts on his own dps/survivability/sustainability, rather than contributing the raid buffs....yeah, probably shouldn't be raiding.

#1819SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2frozenkex
I dont know if this was brought up before, but id like someone to tell their opinion on how envenom would perform in DPE compared to rupture using t6 equivalent gear, having 4/5 vile poisons (20/41 spec) AND considering each envenom is occassional and performed ONLY when Stormstrike (20% more nature damage)debuff is up, which is tricky , but possible.
#1820SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2
Edited onundefined		Left
Originally Posted by frozenkex
I dont know if this was brought up before, but id like someone to tell their opinion on how envenom would perform in DPE compared to rupture using t6 equivalent gear, having 4/5 vile poisons (20/41 spec) AND considering each envenom is occassional and performed ONLY when Stormstrike (20% more nature damage)debuff is up, which is tricky , but possible.
Do the calc. It's going to depend on gear and stats. A lot.

For the sake of argument, let's pick 2500 AP, 35% crit. (IE, high end stats.)

Both rupture and envenom are not mitigated by armor. We'll evaluate for with or without mangle up, as well as with or without Stormstrike

Rupture
Damage = 1000 + 0.24*2500 = 1600
Damage w/ Mangle = 1600*1.3 = 2080
DPE = 1600/25 = 64
DPE w/ Mangle = 2080/25 = 83.2

Envenom
Damage = (900 + 2500*0.15)*1.16*1.35 ~= 1997
Damage w/ Stormstrike = 1997*1.2 = 2396
DPE = 1997/35 = 57
DPE w/ Stormstrike = 2396/35 = 68
But, you also lose your Deadly stack for a few seconds, which is a big chunk of lost DPS.

In short, the DPE is marginally better for Envenom if Stormstrike is up but Mangle is down, but you lose your Deadly stack. Losing your deadly stack is a huge chunk of lost DPS, but it might be ok in situations where you are supposed to "stop DoTs" or if the mob is going to die. (Although, if the mob is about to die you shouldn't Rupture anyway.) The comparison is actually more favorable for Envenom with T5 2pc, since you tack on an extra 200 base damage to Envenom.

If Envenom crits, it is worth it, as the crit more than makes up for the lost DP stack. So Mutilate rogues, for example, can use Envenom to great effect coupled with Cold Blood. (Anecdotally, on a Netherspite kill I used Envenom to wipe my DP stack after holding the blue beam for nearly a whole phase. It crit for 13k.)
Last edited by Left : 01/17/08 at 3:23 PM. Reason: I speel gud
#1821SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2• songster
Originally Posted by frozenkex
I dont know if this was brought up before, but id like someone to tell their opinion on how envenom would perform in DPE compared to rupture using t6 equivalent gear, having 4/5 vile poisons (20/41 spec) AND considering each envenom is occassional and performed ONLY when Stormstrike (20% more nature damage)debuff is up, which is tricky , but possible.
Extremely poorly. Envenom is worse than Eviscerate, which is in turn worse than Rupture. And you should bear in mind that taking the Stormstrike proc (which is pretty much impossible in practice) doesn't do as much as you think for raid DPS, since you're reducing the DPS of whoever would have got the Stormstrike if you didn't.

Use Envenom as the last finisher on a dying mob, if you don't need to refresh your S'n'D. Ignore it at all other times. Unless you're Mutilate, when the higher crit and faster poison stacking may make it useful.
#1822SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2• Latito
Originally Posted by Left
Rupture
Damage = 1000 + 0.24*2500 = 1600
Damage w/ Mangle = 1600*1.3 = 2080
DPE = 1600/25 = 64
DPE w/ Mangle = 2080/25 = 83.2

Envenom
Damage = (900 + 2500*0.15)*1.16*1.35 ~= 1997
Damage w/ Stormstrike = 1997*1.2 = 2396
DPE = 1997/35 = 57
DPE w/ Stormstrike = 2396/35 = 68
But, you also lose your Deadly stack for a few seconds, which is a big chunk of lost DPS.
If you look at the formulas closely and multiply out the buffs on Envenom from Vile Pois. and Crit rate, you get:
1409 + AP * 0.235
which compares very closely to Rupture's 1000 + AP * 0.24

400 more damage for Envenom (600 w/ 2pc T5) and nearly the same AP modifier, at 35% crit. That said, Mangle's buff is greater and doesn't get used up like Stormstrike (as Songster pointed out). Not to mention envenom costs 40% more energy and kills your DP stack (~70 dps)


Simply put - use Envenom only when the mob won't live for the next ~9 seconds. Ie, your DP stack wouldn't get more than 2-3 more ticks anyways and Rupture definitely won't tick out. In all other circumstances, an untalented Evis is often better should you find yourself in this spot - which is generally only during an AR. On most fights with a single dps target, you will find 1 Evis per AR and 1 Envenom (at the end), rupture the rest of the time. Not a hard-and-fast rule, but a reasonable approximation.

#1824SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2frozenkex

Often mangle debuff wasnt up on some bosses , like Illidari council and i was doing few Envenoms when stormstrike debuff was up (Debuff filter ftw), and i had some 4.8k - 5.3k crits :P. #1825SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2Mojofabulous
Question: Is it better to refresh your SnD too early and continue ss'ing to refresh rupture or to throw in an extra ss or 2 and wait for SnD to tick to 0(close to) then refresh? Currently I do both, kind of a 'what I feel like doing' thing :-)
#1826SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2• Aldriana
It depends on what cycle you're doing. For 5s5r, it's better to refresh immediately and start building towards the next Rupture. For Xs5r compressed cycles, it's generally more effective to throw the extra SS or two with the extra energy (to avoid losing energy to Relentless Strikes non-procs), although doing so risks converting your cycle to 5s5r in short order. In order to maintain the shorter cycle you may need to do some immediate refreshes.

Also note that by "immediate" what I really mean is "as soon as your energy ticks over 65". You should sit there and let your energy tick up to save energy for the next cycle before doing any of these things, and only refresh when you're starting to risk capping out. Generally, I prefer to refresh the instant my energy ticks over 65, as this provides a reasonable buffer but almost never caps out, as even if you get both a regular energy tick and a combat potency proc, your energy doesn't max out.
#1827SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2• Aldriana
So, I was helping a friend with a spreadsheet he was making (on an unrelated topic), when, in the course of helping him with his problem, I figured out how to resolve one of the issues that's been bugging me about this sheet, namely, the need for two different versions of it. I have a pretty good idea now how to fix the incompatibility between OO and Excel in the gear recommendations that has been causing the need for two versions. I'll test for certain when I get home from work tonight.

Now, that got me thinking - as long as I'm recoding the recommendation boxes anyway, why not fix some other issues while I'm at it? In particular, the ring and trinket recommendations have always bugged me. But then, of course, there's the question of, "what is the right behavior there anyway?". So here's my current thinking about how to change the gear recommenders:

1) Remove the gear you're currently wearing from the recommendations. It's not at all useful to have a row in the recommendations consisting of "The helm you're wearing is exactly as good as the helm you're wearing" - that's tautological. So rather than the current behavior where, for instance, my bracer recommendations are:

Insidious Bands 26.86
Deadly Cuffs 7.98
Swiftstrike Bracers 0.00

It would instead read:

Insidious Bands 26.86
Deadly Cuffs 7.98
Master Assassin Wristwraps -9.30

While this is a little odd in that it's no longer displaying the "top" 3 bracers, it's reporting what's in some sense more useful - the top 3 bracers that you don't already have, and how they compare.

2) All ring recommendations will be performed relative to poorer of your two rings. So, right now the ring recommendations are fairly redundant. I propose ripping out the 6 cells that currently recommend the top 3 upgrades to ring 1 and the top 3 upgrades to ring 2 and replacing it with a list of the top 5 rings (that you're not already wearing, as per point 1) and how they compare to your inferior ring. This thereby tells you how much of an upgrade you'd actually observe by obtaining that ring, which strikes me as more useful.

3) Trinket recommendations would work the same as rings; you'll get the best trinkets you're not already wearing, and how they compare to your inferior trinket. I might also try to adjust the table to make room for a 3rd trinket recommendation, though we'll have to see how big a job that is.

So, that's the proposal. Comments? Ideas? Anything else I should fix about it while I'm at it?

In other news, I would like feedback on what people perceive to be "typical raid buffs" for a 25-man raid. When I initially filled in the raid buffs, I did it based on what was typical for the guild I was in at the time, and haven't really updated it since - despite having changed guilds to one that uses a somewhat different combination of buffs (much more use of Curse of Recklessness, for instance). So my question is: what buffs do people want to see as the "default" set that the sheet downloads with? Is there some "typical" set of buffs that it should start with, or should I just update it to what my current guild does and let anyone who wants something different change it? Thoughts?
#1828SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2Arindelest
Originally Posted by Aldriana

I think probably the default raid buffs look something like (although I'd like to see what other rogues out think is "normal" -- correct me if I'm off base here) what I'm about to list. It seems that most of the Hyjal/BT rogues I've met tend to have a group with at least a warrior and a shammy.

Imp Fortitude, Imp Gift, Imp Battle Shout, Imp Blessing of Might, Unleashed Rage, Blessing of Kings(??), Imp Hunter's Mark, Expose Weakness(??), Flask of Relentless Assault, Spicy Hot Talbuk, Imp Strength of Earth Totem, Curse of Recklessness, Sunder Armor, Faerie Fire, Mangle, Heroism (1).

I might add Haste Potions on cooldown, because, being as cheap as they are compared to how much money you can make, there's really no reason not to use them if you're doing progression fights.

#1830SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2Left
Those recommendation upgrades sound great, particularly for trinkets and rings. (I had to dig some today because DST was the only trinket upgrade listed for me, and I was like "Duh". But I'm not likely to get a DST since we don't do Gruul anymore and my success pugging the place has been next to nil. Thus, I wanted to see what was next on the list.)

As for "typical" buffs, here is what is typical for me. (My guild is a mid-level raiding guild. We're halfway through SSC and have some TK experience, but we don't do enough hours per week to be considered hardcore end-game.) I'll follow the list with some discussion.

My "typical" Buffs
Kings
Might (0/5 improved)
Salv
Mark of the Wild (5/5 improved)
Fort (2/2 improved)
Windfury (2/2 improved)
Strength of Earth (2/2 improved)
Unleashed Rage
Heroism
Leader of the Pack
Battle Shout (usually 0/5 improved)
Spicy Hot Talbuk
Elixir of Major Agility (although for real progression I'll grab a flask)

Relevant Boss Debuffs
Sunderx5
Faerie Fire (0/3 improved)
Misery
Mangle

Discussion
Our typical melee group is Enh Shaman/Warrior/Feral Druid/Rogue/something, where the something is a rogue or a warrior. Usually, our warrior is prot (hence we don't get improved battle shout); he just resides in our group for tanking trash pulls. We don't run with a survival hunter, and our balance druid does not use imp. faerie fire. Our paladins are usually 41/20/0, so they don't have imp. might. (Also, the number of paladins we have in raid is highly variable, so even if one did have it we might not see it that much.)

I would say, for improved buffs only put as default improved buffs that are usually taken. For example, imp. mark is taken a lot because tree druids have plenty of talent points to play with. Imp. faerie fire and imp. shouts often aren't taken, since they are talents for classes with less wiggle room.

EDIT: I should mention that our locks usually run Curse of Shadows and Curse of Elements to help the casters, not Curse of Recklessness.
#1831SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2• Latito
List of buffs I get: (with comments)
Imp Fort. - Every priest, holy or shadow or disc has this. Highly unlikely to have no priests in a raid
Imp Gift. - Every resto druid has this, if no resto druids in the raid I'm sure a feral picked it up. Highly unlikely to have no druids in a raid
Imp BS - DPS warriors, Arms or Fury all have this pretty much
Imp BoM - Most guilds have at least 2 pallies, and they are generally coordinated enough to get that talent
BoK - What % of guilds have 3+ pallies? I generally have 2 or 3.. Kings is therefore on my 50% of the time
Imp Hunter's Mark - A lot of hunters tend to grab Efficiency, not sure how many guilds have a hunter who picks this up. I don't think any of the hunters in my guild have it, I can double check though.
Expose Weakness - Not really a "common" buff. Majority of raiding hunters are BM, of the guilds on my server at a T6 lvl, I think 1 has a permanent Survival hunter.
Flask - yep (can you add in Elixir of Demonslaying as a buff too, awesome for Hyjal and I keep adding it each release :P)
hit food - yep
Imp SoE, Imp WF, UR - yep. can you add a 3rd GoA totem.. "twisted goa" with an 80% uptime? I generally add this line in myself as well.. just normal goa * 0.8. Theoretically a shaman could achieve 85% goa uptime (and 100% WF).. but GCD limitations and overlapping tend to screw this up a bit, 80% is (if I remember right) a generally accepted uptime for twisted goa.
Sunder, Normal Faerie Fire - yep
CoR - don't normally get this, not sure what guilds do.
Mangle - always
Bloodlust - 1 (since this is "long-term" dps.. I guess we don't need to factor in that most fights are ~3-4 min long)
#1832SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2• Aldriana
So, there are some buffs that are pretty obvious. Almost all guilds are going to run with Imp PW:F and Imp GotW. Pretty much everyone is going to have Battle Shout, Blessing of Might and Windfury at some level - and if you have Windfury, you probably also have Strength of Earth and Heroism. Mangle is pretty common these days, but not everyone has it. And I think it's pretty reasonable to assume that people will be using consumables (Flask + Food).

On the other hand, there's some buffs that are clearly pretty rare. I think it's safe to say that guilds where you have Improved Faerie Fire or Heroic Presence are few and far between, for example.

However, in between, there are some buffs that are common but not universal. Examples that spring to mind would be Blessing of Kings (depending on # of pallies) and Curse of Recklessness. Some guilds use them, some don't. Similarly, the availability of Improved versions of the buffs. I think it's more common than not to have Imp Battle Shout, but Imp WF is less clear to me.

So, the general idea is this. I could try to specify some middle-of-the-road "most people will be about this buffed" setup. This would probably be something like Imp Fort, Imp GotW, Imp Battle Shout, Imp BoMight, Kings, Imp Hunter's Mark, Flask, Talbuk, Str of Earth, Sunders, FF, Mangle, Heroism, and WF/DP. This level of buff is probably pretty similar to what most people have.

Alternately, I could use what's typical of my guild, which is that plus Solarian's Sapphire, Curse of Recklessness, and Drums (under the assumption that what matters most in terms of maximizing DPS is how you do on progression fights, where popping a Drum every cooldown is totally reasonable - particularly with as cheap as they've gotten).

Problem with this is that there are probably guilds that don't use CoR, but regularly have an enhancement shaman so we should have *Imp* Str of Earth, *Imp* WF, and Unleashed Rage. Or, they might have a feral druid in the group for LotP. Or... well, you get the idea.

Regarding Bloodlust/Heroism: in practice, one probably gets a more accurate estimate by bumping this to 2 to simulate one heroism in a 5 min fight. Should I do this, or leave it in "indefinite sustained DPS" mode?
#1833SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2◊ Shaker
Personal preferences - I think an enhancement shaman is a pretty good bet for most people in progressive groups. Also, I'm not sure Improved Hunter's Mark is really that common - it's a very small buff (like what, 110 AP?) for 5 points that the hunter can spend on a better talent at that point in the tree. I know our hunters don't have it, and 2 of them are very min/max-y.

Also, I think the average fight length is still closer to 10 minutes than 5, especially if you're goal is to make this more representative of progression fights (a la drums). That being said, I don't have any T6 experience, sooo...

#1835SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2• Latito
All this talk about buffs is to determine the appropriate defaults - not which buffs are available.

Re: Fight Length
At a T5 level, yes.. most fights are 10 min (enrage timers). Hydross, Leo, FLK, VR all have 10 min enrages. Lurker, Vashj, Alar, Morogrim all last around 10 minutes roughly. Solarian is a bit shorter, Kael a bit longer. In T6 content however.. Rage, Anetheron, Kaz, Najentus, Akama and Teron are all in the 3-4 min range. Azgalor, Archi, Supremus, BB, RoS and Mother are all 5-7 min which leaves only Council at ~10 and Illidan at ~15. I'd say leave it at "indefinate" mode and people can tweak if they want to get a closer estimate for a given fight to compare their actual performance to theoretical.

Either way you slice it, Ald.. you can't get the exact buffs right for everyone, not even the majority of people. Everyone ends up having to review all the buffs to double check them anyways, perhaps default them ALL to off?
#1836SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2• Aldriana
Originally Posted by Koosai
So a couple of suggestions:
1) Could other classes' talents that are on the buff list that have more than 1 rank have a drop down menu? Aka, could I select 4/5 imp might.
Short answer: yeah, that'd probably be a better way of doing it. In reality, the whole buffs sheet could use a rewrite. As for when I'll get around to that? I have absolutely no idea.

2) I recall this being discussed along time ago, probably 50+ pages, so I don't recall if this was in the sheet or ever got added. Hmm, sentence not coming out coherently... I'll try an example, lets say I am looking at glove upgrades, can the sheet look at all my stats from all my gear except my gloves and then evaluate upgrades by what hand items are best and then compare their ap to the ones I have selected? I believe this will give a more accurate representation, if the sheet doesn't do it already.
It's been suggested, but it's really not possible in spreadsheets unless you do lots of macro stuff, which I've been trying to avoid. When/if I get around to releasing something in a real programming language, I will definitely have something like that.

All this talk about buffs almost sounds like you are thinking of removing some, I hope that is not the case. I don't see how they can really make things much harder once you have already implimented them and it is really nice to be able to check off everyone I get.
Nah, nothing is getting removed; I'm just thinking of changing which ones are on be default.

One last note that has been bothering me for a while, why do you always set the default weighting to weighted? I know personally I always forget and am puzzled for a while after I get a new version of the sheet. Also I'm pretty sure alot of people have had some questions that related to that(why is agi rated higher than hit).
Because I'm trying to encourage good practices in rogue gearing. I think a lot of people underestimate/ignore the value of defensive stats on equipment, and I for one think it's a mistake. I'm not saying offense isn't important - it is. The weighting of defensive stats in this is really pretty darn low. In particular, the trade off is something like 1 DPS = 65 HP. That is, you will gain 65 hit points for every 1 DPS you sacrifice, which strikes me as a not unreasonable tradeoff. So I offer a way for people to turn it off if they want to, but the default is set to what I believe to be the right way to assess gear - considering both it's offensive and defensive mods.

Originally Posted by Latito
Either way you slice it, Ald.. you can't get the exact buffs right for everyone, not even the majority of people. Everyone ends up having to review all the buffs to double check them anyways, perhaps default them ALL to off?
It's a valid point, but my counterargument would be that while people really *should* look at the buffs page and tune it for themselves, I'm not sure how many people actually do. I have the perception that a lot of more casual users just open it up, punch in the stuff on the front page, and go never notice or care that there are additional pages. Hence, to try to give the best possible values for this sort of casual user, it seems like it would be good to have some reasonable selection of raid buffs in.

Possible Dirty Deeds bug?
Ive noticed when playing around with your spreadsheet to try and find a good gear selection, that as soon as you add 1 point into Dirty Deeds (or the full 2) the "Optimal Hit" drops by like, 80 or so points. Given the nature of this talent I find it unlikely this was intentional?

Tried going back through the thread to the point where you put a note about the introduction of Dirty Deeds into the spreadsheet and found no reasoning for this, so could it be looked into?


After playing with the "other" spreadsheet (the DPS one) I kept getting odd results which seemed to indicate that Hemo build would be far superior for my weapons / gear selection to combat (which again, seems a little unlikely?) so gave yours a try, but noticed Dirty Deeds was massively reducing the Optimal Hit.

Is this due to Hemo not requiring as much hit, due to lack of CP procs, in which case, surely Optimal Hit would drop when selecting Hemo, not Dirty Deeds? (In which case I still find it unlikely that it would suggest losing around 80 Hit rating?)


Cheers
Last edited by Devilrogue : 01/19/08 at 4:03 AM.
#1841SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2• Aldriana
Well, there may be an underlying bug, but my guess is that what is happening is that putting that point in dirty deeds increases the value of agility to be greater than the value of hit; hence, without that point, it recommends socketing with hit, and after that it recommends socketing with agi.

Note also that you probably have the sheet set on "weighted total" (the default), so that's socketing for a weighted combination of damage and survivability; if you out it on "Offense" you will most likely find that hit is optimal with or without the point in Dirty Deeds.
#1842SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2Devilrogue
After a little more testing, It seems that if you have "Spicy Hot Talbulk" set to "yes" in the buffs section, The "Optimal Hit" only drops when Hemo is selected, regardless of Dirty Deeds selection, However.. if you set it to "no", the "Optimal Hit" only drops when Dirty Deeds is selected, regardless of whether you choose Hemo or not.

Hope that helps shed some light on what might be the issue? (I can understand hit dropping when Hemo is selected, given the lack of hit requirement for CP procs in a Hemo build, but its still dropping by almost 80 rating, is that reasonable?, it was suggesting an "Optimal Hit" of just 216 or so?)


Also... I had it set to "Offensive" rather than weighted, but it still valued 8AGI instantly when this "bug" was reproduced.
#1843SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2• Aldriana
So, the thing is, "Optimal Hit" has nothing to do with the amount of hit you optimally want to have. What it means is that if you socketed every piece of gear that you are currently wearing optimally, you would have that amount of hit. So all you're seeing is the transition point where agi passes hit, and all the socketing recommendations change from hit gems to agi gems.

Really, I should probably just take that cell out - it seems to cause more confusion than it resolves, and the original reason for it's existence (warning people if socketing that way would put them over the hit cap) has become far less relevant since the hit cap increased, not to mention that a lot of the newer itemization has a lot less hit on it.
#1844SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2Devilrogue
Originally Posted by Aldriana
So, the thing is, "Optimal Hit" has nothing to do with the amount of hit you optimally want to have. What it means is that if you socketed every piece of gear that you are currently wearing optimally, you would have that amount of hit. So all you're seeing is the transition point where agi passes hit, and all the socketing recommendations change from hit gems to agi gems.

Really, I should probably just take that cell out - it seems to cause more confusion than it resolves, and the original reason for it's existence (warning people if socketing that way would put them over the hit cap) has become far less relevant since the hit cap increased, not to mention that a lot of the newer itemization has a lot less hit on it.

#1845SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2Jakani
Originally Posted by Devilrogue

(Im trying to get a feel of where to stop worrying about hit rating in such a build, given the lack of CP etc... requiring less hit rating and perhaps allowing more atk power orientated stats (AGI mainly) cus both spreadsheets Ive worked with seem to indicate Tri-spec as giving far superior DPS to combat, given my current gear. Unfortunatly armory is down at the moment and Im still screwing with spec's and gems, so I look kinda messed up lol :p

So to clarify, can anyone give insight a desireable ammount of hit rating for Hemo Tri-spec builds, been trying gem swaps and food swaps etc.. and Ill be damned if I can find the balance :o
To repeat what Aldrianna said, check these things first:
1. At the top of the DPS Sheet, under where you select race, you can select an Offensive/Defensive ratio. If yours is set to Weighted Total, you'll sometimes find that due to the dodge and armor bonus of agi, agi is a better socketing option than hit. If you're only concerned about DPS, change it to Offensive.
2. If you don't have Sword spec and/or WF, agi often surpasses hit rating.

As far as finding that optimal hit level, the spreadsheet is already telling you what you need to do to maximize your DPS. If you configure your buffs and weighting options correctly, the optimal socket suggestions will help you reach your maximum DPS in current gear.

To once again flesh out what's happening with Optimal Hit: the box is showing you what your hit WOULD be IF you socketed according to the sheet suggestions. Its only purpose is in letting you know whether or not socketing "optimally" will take you over the hit cap. It is not giving you an amount of hit to shoot for, necessarily. The reason Dirty Deeds is dropping your optimal hit rating is because DD increases yellow damage only, which is buffed by agi and not hit. This is causing your socket recommendations to switch from hit to agi, thus dropping the optimal hit value.
#1846SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2Devilrogue
Already made sure race etc.. was correct, aswell as being set to Offensive.

I do realise the main reason for the spreadsheet was to try to indicate when people are over the hitcap, rather than provide them with a "goal" to aim for, in regards to hit, but like Aldrianna says, "Optimal Hit" causes many confusions, it either needs to be renamed to some slightly more accurate description, or hidden totally.

That said, even taking into account what DD does for yellow attacks, I find it rather odd that with just 1 point in it, the spreadsheet would instantly think its better to go all out for AGI, than hit, which would have resulted in a Hit Rating of around 220, at which point I find it unlikely that the increased AGI would outweight the large ammount of misses your white dmg would be experiencing at that point.
#1847SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2Jakani
Originally Posted by Devilrogue
That said, even taking into account what DD does for yellow attacks, I find it rather odd that with just 1 point in it, the spreadsheet would instantly think its better to go all out for AGI, than hit, which would have resulted in a Hit Rating of around 220, at which point I find it unlikely that the increased AGI would outweight the large ammount of misses your white dmg would be experiencing at that point.
One thing you could look at is the DamageCalcs sheet. To see it, Go to Format>Sheet>Show>DamageCalcs>Ok .

Row 11 of that sheet shows the relative value of all your various stats. If you compare Agi to Hit, (columns D and G, respectively), you'll probably find that they're almost identical. This is why the sheet is so sensitive to even 1 pt in DD. If you want to know where the point of inflection is, just start socketing by following the recommendations. If you ever reach the point where the value of hit passes agi due to low hit values, the recommendations will change. At that point, Agi and hit are almost equal.

On a sidenote, are you sword spec? Do you have windfury selected? If not, then hit may not out value agi. Using a tri-spec build, you'll have even lower hit value due to the lack of combat potency. The reason hit is so widely accepted as the max DPS standard for rogues is because most high-end rogues are running combat swords with WF.
#1848SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2Devilrogue
Originally Posted by Jakani
One thing you could look at is the DamageCalcs sheet. To see it, Go to Format>Sheet>Show>DamageCalcs>Ok .

Row 11 of that sheet shows the relative value of all your various stats. If you compare Agi to Hit, (columns D and G, respectively), you'll probably find that they're almost identical. This is why the sheet is so sensitive to even 1 pt in DD. If you want to know where the point of inflection is, just start socketing by following the recommendations. If you ever reach the point where the value of hit passes agi due to low hit values, the recommendations will change. At that point, Agi and hit are almost equal.

On a sidenote, are you sword spec? Do you have windfury selected? If not, then hit may not out value agi. Using a tri-spec build, you'll have even lower hit value due to the lack of combat potency. The reason hit is so widely accepted as the max DPS standard for rogues is because most high-end rogues are running combat swords with WF.

Indeed true, my current gear set makes combat not that viable acording to a few spreadsheet tests Ive ran. Ive got a fair bit of haste going on (from DST and Dragonstrike mainhand), aswell as a decent ammount of armor ignore (WSC, Executioner proc, and serrated blades) and in the DPS sheet at least, Tri-spec comes out the clear winner on the DPS charts for me.

However finding a balance of hit rating vs AGI (or maybe pure AP, Ive been wondering about the idea of a high armor-ignore, high AP tri-spec for a while) isnt so easy, especially as having decent armor ignore (procs or not) really does boost white dmg, which requires more hit, whereas of course, DD tends to put the imputus (spelling?) on AGI for the extra yellow damage when below the threshold, at least in the spreadsheet.

If the Armory was working Im sure you guys would see from my current gear-set the predicament Im stuck in at the moment lol

Alternately, I could use what's typical of my guild, which is that plus Solarian's Sapphire, Curse of Recklessness, and Drums (under the assumption that what matters most in terms of maximizing DPS is how you do on progression fights, where popping a Drum every cooldown is totally reasonable - particularly with as cheap as they've gotten).
Perhaps you could put in a section where you fill in your group makeup, and the sheet makes its best guess as to what buffs you get from that?

You'd have 4 dropdown boxes to fill in the other members of your group, and then a second set of tickboxes to specify other classes in the raid. Thus you could tell it that your melee group is (Self, Rogue2, Rogue3, DPSwar, Enh shaman), and that the raid as a whole has a moonkin, a feral druid and 3 paladins, and a hunter with improved Mark.

The sheet would then know to give you shouts, totems, 3 Blessings, Imp FF, Imp Mark and Mangle debuff, but not LoTP.

For the majority of people, that approach would be more intuitive than memorising the list of buffs provided to the party/raid by every class. The more technically-minded could always tick a manual override button and set a precise complement of buffs/debuffs.

Using my current template / gear (sword / T5ish) the spreadsheet tells me i have an optimal hit at 271.
If i change my current Bloodlust brooch for a DST the optimal hit becomes 331. It's the first time i have such a difference and i don't understand why in terms of game mechanics.

#1853SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2Fearendil

I know it's true of course but i still don't understand how an AP loss (which is not so great) vs the haste proc from DST (never been lucky with any trinkets) can demand such a large difference on my hit rating. It's just one piece of gear even if it's the most powerfull trinket in game.
#1854SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2♦ Aldriana
I'd recommend reading the preceding page or so of posts, which discuss a very similar issue. Fundamentally: you passed the breakpoint where hit becomes more important than agility, and so the socketing recommendations all change. The sheet has no ability to socket your gear as a whole for maximal DPS; it can only look at the situation slot by slot. Hence, when you reach the point where hit passes agility in terms of quality, all the socketing recommendations change at once, so the optimal socketing of your gear changes as well. This doesn't means that you should start trading out gear or gems to get to that level of hit - there's no such thing as a "magic" or "optimal" amount of hit to wind up with. Instead, it simply means that, going forward, it's probably worthwhile to socket new pieces of gear in a more hit-heavy fashion than you have in the past.
#1855SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2Tosa
Originally Posted by Fearendil
I know it's true of course but i still don't understand how an AP loss (which is not so great) vs the haste proc from DST (never been lucky with any trinkets) can demand such a large difference on my hit rating. It's just one piece of gear even if it's the most powerfull trinket in game.
I believe it's because hit increases DST's uptime, and the proc is so strong that you'd want it up as much as possible.
#1856SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2nelalas
Originally Posted by Aldriana
In other news, I would like feedback on what people perceive to be "typical raid buffs" for a 25-man raid. So my question is: what buffs do people want to see as the "default" set that the sheet downloads with? Is there some "typical" set of buffs that it should start with, or should I just update it to what my current guild does and let anyone who wants something different change it? Thoughts?

Anyhow, like many of the previous posters, our guild builds a melee group around an enhancement shaman and a dps warrior. We rarely, if ever, get our feral druid in our group for he is stationed with the tanks for threat generation (not to mention that the druid is also tanking and gets other benefits of that group). Therefore, we get the Mangle debuff but not Leader of the Pack. Generally speaking, I do not have to change the buffs page around too much when I download a new version of the spreadsheet but I still double-check it nonetheless, which lends support to the "just turn all options off and let people input their own" suggestion.

In addition, one of our druids is taking a trip up the balance tree, bestowing Improved Faerie Fire upon our bosses. I believe it is safe to say that we are looking for any reason to keep raids entertaining until Sunwell is released. #1857SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2♦ Aldriana
Originally Posted by songster
Perhaps you could put in a section where you fill in your group makeup, and the sheet makes its best guess as to what buffs you get from that?

You'd have 4 dropdown boxes to fill in the other members of your group, and then a second set of tickboxes to specify other classes in the raid. Thus you could tell it that your melee group is (Self, Rogue2, Rogue3, DPSwar, Enh shaman), and that the raid as a whole has a moonkin, a feral druid and 3 paladins, and a hunter with improved Mark.

The sheet would then know to give you shouts, totems, 3 Blessings, Imp FF, Imp Mark and Mangle debuff, but not LoTP.

For the majority of people, that approach would be more intuitive than memorising the list of buffs provided to the party/raid by every class. The more technically-minded could always tick a manual override button and set a precise complement of buffs/debuffs.
I thought about this approach, but it seems to me that there's enough complexity that it would be challenging to do this well. I think a better approach might be to group the buffs by class and spec rather than in the sort of ad hoc order they're in right now; so, for instance, if you have an enhancement shaman, you go to the "shaman" section which has all shaman buffs and perhaps some notes of which spec they're associated with. This will provide some of the guidance you refer to, without needing to ask a laundry list of slightly subtle questions ("how many paladins are in the raid?", "have any of your hunters specced Imp Mark?", "if you have 2 or fewer warlocks, do you have more melee dps or caster dps?")

Originally Posted by nelalas
As a side note, we do occasionally raid with a retribution paladin in the melee group (when he raids), which gives us Improved Sanctity Aura (+2% damage) as well as Improved Seal of the Crusader (+3% crit). In addition, one of our druids is taking a trip up the balance tree, bestowing Improved Faerie Fire upon our bosses. I believe it is safe to say that we are looking for any reason to keep raids entertaining until Sunwell is released. Anyway, in the case that the buff sheet ever gets re-written, I'm throwing out a suggestion to include the retribution paladin contributions. Just another line on a post-it note, at most.
Ret pallies basically just contribute Imp Sanctity Aura, right? I suppose it might be worth adding, but as 1) ret pallies are somewhat rare in raiding, and 2) it doesn't change gear ordering in any way whatsoever, it hasn't really been a priority. All it would do is add a scalar multiple to total DPS, and as DPS estimates aren't the primary function of this sheet I'm less worried about that than I might be.

I don't know. I may work it in, or not. I want to improve the usability of the buffs sheet at some point, and a big part of that will be reducing clutter, so we'll see how it fits in.
#1858SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2Fearendil
Originally Posted by Aldriana
I'd recommend reading the preceding page or so of posts, which discuss a very similar issue. Fundamentally: you passed the breakpoint where hit becomes more important than agility, and so the socketing recommendations all change. The sheet has no ability to socket your gear as a whole for maximal DPS; it can only look at the situation slot by slot. Hence, when you reach the point where hit passes agility in terms of quality, all the socketing recommendations change at once, so the optimal socketing of your gear changes as well. This doesn't means that you should start trading out gear or gems to get to that level of hit - there's no such thing as a "magic" or "optimal" amount of hit to wind up with. Instead, it simply means that, going forward, it's probably worthwhile to socket new pieces of gear in a more hit-heavy fashion than you have in the past.
I understand perfectly the "magical" part commentary. All stats scale with one another and so on ... I was surprised to find that the inflection point was so important a change and i thought it was far from my current gear (since i haven't got hyjal/BT acces yet) which got me curious.

Guess i'll have to loot a tsunami and play a bit with my gems ...

Thank you all for your response.
#1859SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2♦ Aldriana
The point is, it's really not an important change. At that level of gear, Agi and Hit have almost identical benefit. So when you cross from one side of the line to the other - yes, all the socketing recommendations change, but if you look at the amount of damage you do socketed full agi vs the amount you do socketed full hit the difference between the two will be trivial. It's not going to make a big difference in your damage either way. But the fact is, the sheet has to recommend *something* so it recommends socketing with whichever happens to be better - even if it's only by .01 AP.
#1860SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2Latito

Ret pallies basically just contribute Imp Sanctity Aura, right?
They also have +3% crit thing on the boss - everyone in the raid has 3% higher crit vs their target, 100% uptime (baring they don't get like 3 or 4 dodges in a row on a 6-10 sec CD instant attack)

#1862SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2nelalas
Originally Posted by Aldriana

I don't know. I may work it in, or not. I want to improve the usability of the buffs sheet at some point, and a big part of that will be reducing clutter, so we'll see how it fits in.
True enough, however I quote the first post of this thread:
Originally Posted by Aldriana
Q: This sheet gives different answers than the Rogue DPS sheet for the value of item/buff/talent point/whatever X. What gives?
A: At the risk of sounding like an ass: because this sheet is right and the other is wrong.

To expand on that a bit: there are a number of modeling differences between this and the Rogue DPS sheet, so they will frequently generate different answers for the value of various pieces of gear. Thus, they disagree because one is more accurately modeling the effect than the other. As a general rule, I'm of the opinion that the accuracy of this sheet is higher (although I may be biased - if I didn't believe that, I wouldn't have bothered creating this sheet.) Ultimately, it's a matter of which sheet you trust more, and that you need to decide for yourself.
I have used both sheets and I trust this one more. Thus, while I recognize that the primary function of this spreadsheet is to accurately recommend the most optimal pieces of gear, enchantments, and gems, I also pay attention to its recommended energy use cycles as well as its DPS estimate. Now these last two functions may be secondary but they are indeed useful. I wonder how many rogues out there compare their actual DPS to theorectical DPS in hopes of finding reasons for deviations and, ultimately, ways to improve their play. I am making no demands here to be sure; I was simply suggesting that if time and desire ever permit the buff page to be re-designed there are some (albeit rare) buffs that could be included. =)

Last edited by Vic : 01/21/08 at 1:31 AM.
#1872SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2♦ Aldriana
I understand not wanting to read through 75 pages, but the answer to your question is in the first post of the thread, so I'd appreciate it if you'd at least read that. Also, it's answered in the last page and a half, so you might try that as well.

Columns C, E, and H are in EAP (Effective Attack Power, aka APEP, Attack Power Equivalence Points). If you're wondering why it's not in AEP: because AEP is a bad baseline measure to use for stat comparison, and I was using EAP before AEP was invented and see no reason to change.
#1873SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2Vic

#1875SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.2♦ Aldriana
Well, I'd originally left it out because it's itemized pretty poorly for rogues - it's really a lot more of a feral druid item. That said, plugging it in, it does appear to be one of the better options for a pre-raid/early raid rogue... I place it behind 6th, ahead of anything you can get from T4 or Heroics, but behind anything in ZA, T5, or T6. So, you're probably right that I should include it.

In the meantime, you can add it yourself, if you so desire. Just unhide the armor sheet, insert a row in the middle of the belts block, copy one of the other belts over into the empty row, and update the name and stats.
